sodium bicarbonate.definition: A systemic alkalizer and antacid used to relieve heartburn, acid indigestion, and to treat metabolic acidosis.
sodium bicarbonate.mechanism: Neutralizes gastric acid and increases plasma bicarbonate, buffering excess hydrogen ion concentration.

dosage.adults: 325-2000 mg orally 1-4 times daily as antacid; 1 mEq/kg IV for metabolic acidosis.
dosage.children: Dose varies by indication; consult guidelines.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if clearly needed (FDA category C).

citric acid.definition: An alkalinizing agent used to make urine less acidic and prevent kidney stones.
citric acid.mechanism: Metabolized to bicarbonate, increases urinary pH.

dosage.adults: 10-30 mL oral solution after meals and at bedtime.
dosage.children: 5-15 mL oral solution after meals and at bedtime.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if clearly needed.

sodium citrate.definition: An alkalinizing agent used to treat metabolic acidosis and prevent kidney stones.
sodium citrate.mechanism: Metabolized to bicarbonate, increases urinary and systemic pH.

dosage.adults: 10-30 mL oral solution after meals and at bedtime.
dosage.children: 5-15 mL oral solution after meals and at bedtime.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if clearly needed.

bethanechol.definition: A cholinergic agonist used to treat urinary retention by stimulating bladder contraction.
bethanechol.mechanism: Stimulates muscarinic receptors, increasing detrusor muscle tone.
indications: Acute postoperative and postpartum urinary retention

special populations.pregnancy: Category C; use only if needed.

pamabrom.definition: A mild diuretic used to relieve bloating and water retention, often in combination with analgesics for menstrual symptoms.
pamabrom.mechanism: Increases renal excretion of water, reducing fluid retention.
indications: Relief of bloating and water retention associated with menstruation

dosage.adults: 50 mg orally up to 4 times daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Consult physician.

vasopressin.definition: A synthetic hormone used to treat diabetes insipidus, vasodilatory shock, and to control bleeding from esophageal varices.
vasopressin.mechanism: Acts on V1 and V2 receptors to increase water reabsorption in kidneys and constrict blood vessels.

dosage.adults: 0.01–0.07 units/min IV infusion for shock; 5–10 units IM or SC for diabetes insipidus.

special populations.pregnancy: Category C; use only if needed.

medroxyprogesterone.definition: A progestin used for contraception, abnormal uterine bleeding, and endometrial hyperplasia prevention.
medroxyprogesterone.mechanism: Binds progesterone receptors, altering endometrial lining and inhibiting gonadotropin release.

dosage.adults: 5–10 mg orally daily for 5–10 days (bleeding); 150 mg IM every 3 months (contraception).

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

norethindrone.definition: A synthetic progestin used for contraception, endometriosis, and abnormal uterine bleeding.
norethindrone.mechanism: Inhibits ovulation, thickens cervical mucus, and alters endometrial lining.

dosage.adults: 0.35–1 mg orally daily (contraception); 5–15 mg daily (other indications).

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

megestrol.definition: A synthetic progestin used to treat anorexia, cachexia, and significant weight loss in AIDS and cancer patients.
megestrol.mechanism: Stimulates appetite and weight gain, has anti-gonadotropic and anti-estrogenic effects.
indications: Anorexia and cachexia in AIDS or cancer

dosage.adults: 400–800 mg orally daily (appetite stimulation); 40–320 mg daily (carcinoma).

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

levonorgestrel.definition: A synthetic progestin used for contraception, emergency contraception, and in hormonal IUDs.
levonorgestrel.mechanism: Inhibits ovulation, thickens cervical mucus, alters endometrial lining.

dosage.adults: 1.5 mg orally as a single dose (emergency contraception); IUD: 52 mg device, replaced every 3–5 years.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

ethinyl estradiol.definition: A synthetic estrogen used in combination with progestins for hormonal contraception and to treat menopausal symptoms.
ethinyl estradiol.mechanism: Binds to estrogen receptors, regulating gene transcription and modulating the development and maintenance of the female reproductive system.

dosage.adults: 20–50 mcg orally daily in combination with a progestin for 21 days per cycle.

contraindications: Active or history of thromboembolic disorders

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.
special populations.breastfeeding: May reduce milk production; caution advised.

norgestimate.definition: A synthetic progestin used in combination with ethinyl estradiol for oral contraception.
norgestimate.mechanism: Inhibits ovulation, thickens cervical mucus, and alters endometrial lining to prevent pregnancy.
indications: Hormonal contraception (in combination with ethinyl estradiol)

dosage.adults: 0.18–0.25 mg orally daily (with 35 mcg ethinyl estradiol) for 21 days per cycle.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

desogestrel.definition: A synthetic progestin used for hormonal contraception, often combined with ethinyl estradiol.
desogestrel.mechanism: Inhibits ovulation and thickens cervical mucus, preventing fertilization.
indications: Hormonal contraception (in combination with ethinyl estradiol)

dosage.adults: 0.15 mg orally daily (with 30 mcg ethinyl estradiol) for 21 days per cycle.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

misoprostol.definition: A synthetic prostaglandin E1 analog used for gastric ulcer prevention, labor induction, and medical abortion.
misoprostol.mechanism: Stimulates uterine contractions and inhibits gastric acid secretion by binding to prostaglandin receptors.

dosage.adults: 200 mcg orally 2–4 times daily for ulcer prevention; 800 mcg vaginally or buccally for abortion protocols.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated for ulcer prevention; indicated for abortion/labor induction.

mifepristone.definition: An antiprogestin used for medical abortion and the treatment of Cushing's syndrome.
mifepristone.mechanism: Blocks progesterone receptors, leading to termination of pregnancy; also blocks glucocorticoid receptors at higher doses.

dosage.adults: 200 mg orally as a single dose for abortion; up to 1200 mg daily for Cushing's syndrome.

special populations.pregnancy: Indicated for abortion; contraindicated otherwise.

oxytocin.definition: A synthetic hormone used to induce labor, control postpartum bleeding, and stimulate uterine contractions.
oxytocin.mechanism: Stimulates uterine smooth muscle contraction by binding to oxytocin receptors.

dosage.adults: 0.5–1 mU/min IV infusion, titrated for labor; 10–40 units in 1 L IV for postpartum hemorrhage.

contraindications: Fetal distress (when delivery is not imminent)

special populations.pregnancy: Indicated for labor induction.

carboprost.definition: A synthetic prostaglandin F2α analog used to treat postpartum hemorrhage and induce abortion.
carboprost.mechanism: Stimulates uterine contractions by binding to prostaglandin receptors.
indications: Postpartum hemorrhage due to uterine atony

dosage.adults: 250 mcg IM every 15–90 minutes as needed (max 2 mg).

contraindications: Active cardiac, pulmonary, renal, or hepatic disease

special populations.pregnancy: Indicated for abortion/postpartum hemorrhage.
special populations.asthma: Use with extreme caution or avoid.

dinoprostone.definition: A synthetic prostaglandin E2 analog used for cervical ripening, labor induction, and abortion.
dinoprostone.mechanism: Relaxes cervical smooth muscle and stimulates uterine contractions.
indications: Cervical ripening prior to labor induction

dosage.adults: 10 mg vaginal insert for up to 12 hours; 20 mg vaginal suppository every 3–4 hours for abortion.

special populations.pregnancy: Indicated for labor induction/abortion.

methotrexate.definition: An antimetabolite and antifolate agent used to treat cancer, autoimmune diseases, and ectopic pregnancy.
methotrexate.mechanism: Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, interfering with DNA synthesis and cell replication.

dosage.adults: 7.5–25 mg orally or parenterally once weekly (RA/psoriasis); cancer dosing varies.
dosage.children: Dosing varies by indication and weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated except for ectopic pregnancy.

cefotaxime.definition: A third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections.
cefotaxime.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe (Category B).

levetiracetam.definition: An anticonvulsant used to treat partial-onset, myoclonic, and generalized tonic-clonic seizures.
levetiracetam.mechanism: Modulates synaptic neurotransmitter release by binding to synaptic vesicle protein SV2A in the brain.

dosage.adults: 500 mg twice daily, may increase gradually up to 1500 mg twice daily.
dosage.children: Dose based on weight and indication; refer to guidelines.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

phenobarbital.definition: A long-acting barbiturate used as an anticonvulsant and sedative.
phenobarbital.mechanism: Enhances GABA-mediated chloride influx, leading to CNS depression.

dosage.adults: 50-100 mg orally or IM/IV once daily or divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if clearly needed; may cause fetal harm.
special populations.elderly: Increased risk of sedation and falls.

phenytoin.definition: A hydantoin anticonvulsant used to control seizures.
phenytoin.mechanism: Stabilizes neuronal membranes and decreases seizure activity by increasing efflux or decreasing influx of sodium ions.

dosage.adults: 100 mg orally three times daily; adjust based on serum levels.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if clearly needed; risk of fetal hydantoin syndrome.

diazepam.definition: A benzodiazepine used for anxiety, muscle spasms, seizures, and alcohol withdrawal.
diazepam.mechanism: Enhances the effect of GABA at the GABA-A receptor, producing CNS depression.

dosage.adults: 2-10 mg orally 2-4 times daily; IV/IM dosing varies by indication.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if clearly needed; risk of fetal harm.

oxcarbazepine.definition: An anticonvulsant used to treat partial-onset seizures.
oxcarbazepine.mechanism: Blocks voltage-sensitive sodium channels, stabilizing hyperexcited neural membranes.

dosage.adults: 600 mg orally twice daily; titrate as needed.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

zonisamide.definition: A sulfonamide anticonvulsant used for partial seizures.
zonisamide.mechanism: Blocks sodium and T-type calcium channels, stabilizing neuronal membranes.

dosage.adults: 100 mg once daily, may increase to 400 mg/day in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

topiramate.definition: An anticonvulsant used for epilepsy and migraine prophylaxis.
topiramate.mechanism: Blocks sodium channels, enhances GABA activity, antagonizes glutamate receptors.

dosage.adults: 25-50 mg once daily, titrate up to 200-400 mg/day.

contraindications: Recent alcohol use with extended-release form

special populations.pregnancy: Increased risk of fetal harm.

valproic acid.definition: A broad-spectrum anticonvulsant used for epilepsy, bipolar disorder, and migraine prophylaxis.
valproic acid.mechanism: Increases GABA levels and inhibits sodium and calcium channels.

dosage.adults: 10-15 mg/kg/day orally in divided doses, titrate as needed.
dosage.children: Same as adults, adjust based on weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated unless no alternatives.

primidone.definition: A barbiturate anticonvulsant used to treat various seizure types.
primidone.mechanism: Metabolized to phenobarbital and PEMA, enhancing GABA activity.

dosage.adults: 100-125 mg at bedtime, increase gradually to 750-1500 mg/day in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if clearly needed.

aspirin.definition: An NSAID and antiplatelet agent used for pain, fever, inflammation, and cardiovascular protection.
aspirin.mechanism: Irreversibly inhibits COX-1 and COX-2, reducing prostaglandin and thromboxane synthesis.

dosage.adults: 325-650 mg orally every 4-6 hours as needed; 81-325 mg daily for antiplatelet effect.
dosage.children: Avoid in viral infections due to risk of Reye's syndrome.

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in third trimester.

nitroglycerin.definition: A nitrate used to treat and prevent angina pectoris.
nitroglycerin.mechanism: Releases nitric oxide, causing vasodilation and reducing cardiac oxygen demand.

dosage.adults: 0.3-0.6 mg sublingually every 5 minutes as needed (max 3 doses in 15 minutes).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

metoprolol.definition: A beta-1 selective blocker used for hypertension, angina, and heart failure.
metoprolol.mechanism: Blocks beta-1 adrenergic receptors, reducing heart rate and cardiac output.

dosage.adults: 25-100 mg orally once or twice daily; IV dosing for acute arrhythmias.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

amlodipine.definition: A calcium channel blocker used to treat hypertension and angina.
amlodipine.mechanism: Inhibits calcium ion influx into vascular smooth muscle and myocardium, causing vasodilation.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

isosorbide mononitrate.definition: A long-acting nitrate used for the prevention of angina pectoris.
isosorbide mononitrate.mechanism: Releases nitric oxide, causing vasodilation and reducing cardiac oxygen demand.

dosage.adults: 30-60 mg orally once daily in the morning; may increase to 120 mg once daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

isosorbide dinitrate.definition: A nitrate used to prevent and treat angina pectoris.
isosorbide dinitrate.mechanism: Releases nitric oxide, causing vasodilation and reducing cardiac oxygen demand.
indications: Prevention and treatment of angina pectoris

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

enoxaparin.definition: A low molecular weight heparin used for prophylaxis and treatment of thromboembolic disorders.
enoxaparin.mechanism: Potentiates antithrombin III, inhibiting factor Xa and IIa.
indications: Deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis and treatment

dosage.adults: Prophylaxis: 40 mg SC once daily; Treatment: 1 mg/kg SC every 12 hours.
dosage.children: Dose based on weight and indication.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

ranolazine.definition: An antianginal agent used to treat chronic angina.
ranolazine.mechanism: Inhibits late phase of inward sodium current in cardiac cells, reducing ischemia.

dosage.adults: 500 mg orally twice daily; may increase to 1000 mg twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

atenolol.definition: A beta-1 selective blocker used for hypertension, angina, and arrhythmias.
atenolol.mechanism: Blocks beta-1 adrenergic receptors, reducing heart rate and cardiac output.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

carvedilol.definition: A non-selective beta and alpha-1 blocker used for heart failure and hypertension.
carvedilol.mechanism: Blocks beta-1, beta-2, and alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, reducing heart rate and vasoconstriction.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

atorvastatin.definition: A statin used to lower cholesterol and reduce risk of cardiovascular disease.
atorvastatin.mechanism: Inhibits HMG-CoA reductase, reducing cholesterol synthesis.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

dextranomer.definition: A polysaccharide used as a wound dressing and to treat fecal incontinence (as dextranomer/hyaluronic acid gel).
dextranomer.mechanism: Absorbs wound exudate and promotes healing; acts as a bulking agent for incontinence.

dosage.adults: Apply to wound as needed; gel: 1 mL per injection site.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

sodium hyaluronate.definition: A viscosupplement used for osteoarthritis of the knee and as an ophthalmic surgical aid.
sodium hyaluronate.mechanism: Acts as a lubricant and shock absorber in joints; maintains eye shape during surgery.

dosage.adults: 20-48 mg intra-articular injection weekly for 3-5 weeks (knee OA).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

acetylcysteine.definition: A mucolytic agent and antidote for acetaminophen overdose.
acetylcysteine.mechanism: Breaks disulfide bonds in mucus, reducing viscosity; replenishes glutathione in acetaminophen toxicity.

dosage.adults: Acetaminophen overdose: 140 mg/kg orally, then 70 mg/kg every 4 hours for 17 doses; Mucolytic: 2-20% inhalation solution.
dosage.children: Same as adults, adjust by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

meloxicam.definition: A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis.
meloxicam.mechanism: Inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX-2 > COX-1), reducing prostaglandin synthesis.

dosage.children: 0.125 mg/kg once daily (juvenile RA, age ≥2 years).

contraindications: History of asthma, urticaria, or allergic-type reactions after NSAIDs

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in third trimester.

naproxen.definition: A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for pain, fever, and inflammation.
naproxen.mechanism: Inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2), reducing prostaglandin synthesis.
contraindications: History of asthma, urticaria, or allergic-type reactions after NSAIDs

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in third trimester.

indomethacin.definition: A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for moderate to severe arthritis and gout.
indomethacin.mechanism: Inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2), reducing prostaglandin synthesis.
contraindications: History of asthma, urticaria, or allergic-type reactions after NSAIDs

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in third trimester.

trolamine salicylate.definition: A topical analgesic and anti-inflammatory agent used for the temporary relief of minor aches and pains of muscles and joints.
trolamine salicylate.mechanism: Salicylate inhibits prostaglandin synthesis; trolamine acts as a vehicle.
indications: Minor aches and pains of muscles and joints

dosage.adults: Apply to affected area not more than 3-4 times daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

sulindac.definition: A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for arthritis and acute gouty arthritis.
sulindac.mechanism: Inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2), reducing prostaglandin synthesis.
contraindications: History of asthma, urticaria, or allergic-type reactions after NSAIDs

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in third trimester.

omeprazole.definition: A proton pump inhibitor used to treat GERD, ulcers, and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
omeprazole.mechanism: Inhibits gastric parietal cell H+/K+ ATPase, suppressing gastric acid secretion.

dosage.children: Dose based on weight and indication.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

pantoprazole.definition: A proton pump inhibitor used to treat GERD, erosive esophagitis, and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
pantoprazole.mechanism: Inhibits gastric parietal cell H+/K+ ATPase, suppressing gastric acid secretion.

dosage.adults: 40 mg orally or IV once daily.
dosage.children: Dose based on weight and indication.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ranitidine.definition: A histamine-2 receptor antagonist used to treat ulcers, GERD, and conditions with excess stomach acid.
ranitidine.mechanism: Blocks H2 receptors on gastric parietal cells, reducing acid secretion.

dosage.adults: 150 mg orally twice daily or 300 mg at bedtime.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

famotidine.definition: A histamine-2 receptor antagonist used to treat ulcers, GERD, and conditions with excess stomach acid.
famotidine.mechanism: Blocks H2 receptors on gastric parietal cells, reducing acid secretion.

dosage.adults: 20-40 mg orally once or twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

lansoprazole.definition: A proton pump inhibitor used to treat GERD, ulcers, and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
lansoprazole.mechanism: Inhibits gastric parietal cell H+/K+ ATPase, suppressing gastric acid secretion.

dosage.children: Dose based on weight and indication.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

esomeprazole.definition: A proton pump inhibitor used to treat GERD, erosive esophagitis, and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
esomeprazole.mechanism: Inhibits gastric parietal cell H+/K+ ATPase, suppressing gastric acid secretion.

dosage.children: Dose based on weight and indication.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

rabeprazole.definition: A proton pump inhibitor used to treat GERD, ulcers, and Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.
rabeprazole.mechanism: Inhibits gastric parietal cell H+/K+ ATPase, suppressing gastric acid secretion.

dosage.children: Dose based on weight and indication.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

sucralfate.definition: A gastrointestinal protectant used to treat and prevent ulcers.
sucralfate.mechanism: Forms a protective barrier over ulcers, shielding them from acid and pepsin.

dosage.adults: 1 g orally 4 times daily before meals and at bedtime.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

dexlansoprazole.definition: A proton pump inhibitor used to treat GERD and erosive esophagitis.
dexlansoprazole.mechanism: Inhibits gastric parietal cell H+/K+ ATPase, suppressing gastric acid secretion.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ibuprofen.definition: A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for pain, fever, and inflammation.
ibuprofen.mechanism: Inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2), reducing prostaglandin synthesis.

dosage.adults: 200-400 mg orally every 4-6 hours as needed.
dosage.children: 5-10 mg/kg orally every 6-8 hours as needed.

contraindications: History of asthma, urticaria, or allergic-type reactions after NSAIDs

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in third trimester.

acetaminophen.definition: An analgesic and antipyretic used for pain and fever.
acetaminophen.mechanism: Inhibits prostaglandin synthesis in the CNS and works peripherally to block pain impulse generation.

dosage.adults: 325-1000 mg orally every 4-6 hours as needed (max 4g/day).

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

diclofenac.definition: A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for pain and inflammation.
diclofenac.mechanism: Inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2), reducing prostaglandin synthesis.
contraindications: History of asthma, urticaria, or allergic-type reactions after NSAIDs

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in third trimester.

nabumetone.definition: A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for pain and inflammation in osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis.
nabumetone.mechanism: Inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2), reducing prostaglandin synthesis.

dosage.adults: 1000 mg orally once daily; may increase to 1500-2000 mg/day in 1-2 divided doses.

contraindications: History of asthma, urticaria, or allergic-type reactions after NSAIDs

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in third trimester.

doxycycline.definition: A tetracycline antibiotic used to treat a wide variety of bacterial infections.
doxycycline.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit.
contraindications: Children under 8 years (except for serious infections)

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid unless no alternatives.

spironolactone.definition: A potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist used for heart failure, hypertension, and hyperaldosteronism.
spironolactone.mechanism: Blocks aldosterone receptors in the distal nephron, increasing sodium and water excretion while retaining potassium.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

minocycline.definition: A tetracycline antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections and acne.
minocycline.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit.

dosage.children: 2 mg/kg initially, then 1 mg/kg every 12 hours (age ≥8 years).

contraindications: Children under 8 years (except for serious infections)

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid unless no alternatives.

clindamycin.definition: A lincosamide antibiotic used to treat serious bacterial infections and acne.
clindamycin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

tretinoin.definition: A topical retinoid used to treat acne vulgaris and photoaging.
tretinoin.mechanism: Modulates epithelial cell growth and differentiation.

dosage.adults: Apply a thin layer to affected area once daily at bedtime (topical).
dosage.children: Safety and efficacy not established for topical use under 12 years.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated (oral); topical form: avoid if possible.

isotretinoin.definition: An oral retinoid used for severe recalcitrant nodular acne.
isotretinoin.mechanism: Reduces sebaceous gland size and sebum production; modulates cell differentiation.

dosage.adults: 0.5-1 mg/kg/day in two divided doses for 15-20 weeks.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to isotretinoin or vitamin A

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated (iPLEDGE program).

benzoyl peroxide.definition: A topical agent with antibacterial and keratolytic properties used to treat acne.
benzoyl peroxide.mechanism: Releases oxygen free radicals that oxidize bacterial proteins and decrease P. acnes.

dosage.adults: Apply to affected area 1-2 times daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

adapalene.definition: A topical retinoid used to treat acne vulgaris.
adapalene.mechanism: Modulates cell differentiation and keratinization, reducing comedone formation.

dosage.adults: Apply a thin layer to affected area once daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

tetracycline.definition: A tetracycline antibiotic used to treat a wide range of bacterial infections.
tetracycline.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit.
contraindications: Children under 8 years (except for serious infections)

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid unless no alternatives.

cephalexin.definition: A first-generation cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections.
cephalexin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

sulfamethoxazole.definition: A sulfonamide antibiotic used in combination with trimethoprim to treat various bacterial infections.
sulfamethoxazole.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial synthesis of dihydrofolic acid by competing with para-aminobenzoic acid.

dosage.adults: Usually combined with trimethoprim (see TMP-SMX dosing).

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in late pregnancy.

trimethoprim.definition: An antibiotic often used in combination with sulfamethoxazole to treat various bacterial infections.
trimethoprim.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial dihydrofolate reductase, blocking folic acid synthesis.

dosage.adults: Usually combined with sulfamethoxazole (see TMP-SMX dosing).

contraindications: Megaloblastic anemia due to folate deficiency

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in first trimester.

metronidazole.definition: An antibiotic and antiprotozoal agent used to treat anaerobic bacterial and certain protozoal infections.
metronidazole.mechanism: Disrupts DNA synthesis in anaerobic bacteria and protozoa.

dosage.adults: 500 mg orally or IV every 8-12 hours.

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in first trimester.

azelaic acid.definition: A topical dicarboxylic acid used to treat acne and rosacea.
azelaic acid.mechanism: Inhibits microbial protein synthesis and keratinization of follicular epidermis.

dosage.adults: Apply to affected area twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

sulfacetamide sodium.definition: A sulfonamide antibiotic used topically for acne and seborrheic dermatitis.
sulfacetamide sodium.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial synthesis of dihydrofolic acid.

dosage.adults: Apply to affected area 1-2 times daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

sulfur.definition: A topical keratolytic and antibacterial agent used to treat acne and seborrheic dermatitis.
sulfur.mechanism: Promotes shedding of keratin and has mild antibacterial properties.

dosage.adults: Apply to affected area 1-3 times daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

ivermectin.definition: An antiparasitic agent used orally for strongyloidiasis and onchocerciasis, and topically for rosacea and lice.
ivermectin.mechanism: Binds to glutamate-gated chloride channels in nerve and muscle cells of parasites, causing paralysis and death.

dosage.adults: Oral: 150-200 mcg/kg as a single dose; Topical: apply once daily (rosacea) or once to scalp (lice).
dosage.children: Oral: same as adults for weight ≥15 kg.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.
special populations.children: Oral form not for children <15 kg.

brimonidine.definition: An alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to lower intraocular pressure in glaucoma and as a topical gel for rosacea.
brimonidine.mechanism: Reduces aqueous humor production and increases uveoscleral outflow (ocular); vasoconstricts cutaneous vessels (topical).

dosage.adults: Ophthalmic: 1 drop in affected eye(s) 2-3 times daily; Topical: apply a pea-sized amount once daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

lamivudine.definition: A nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used to treat HIV and chronic hepatitis B.
lamivudine.mechanism: Inhibits reverse transcriptase, terminating viral DNA chain elongation.

dosage.adults: 150 mg orally twice daily or 300 mg once daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

efavirenz.definition: A non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) used to treat HIV-1 infection.
efavirenz.mechanism: Inhibits HIV-1 reverse transcriptase by binding non-competitively, blocking viral replication.
contraindications: Concurrent use with certain CYP3A4 substrates

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in first trimester.

emtricitabine.definition: A nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used to treat HIV-1 infection and chronic hepatitis B.
emtricitabine.mechanism: Inhibits reverse transcriptase, causing chain termination of viral DNA.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

tenofovir.definition: A nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used to treat HIV-1 infection and chronic hepatitis B.
tenofovir.mechanism: Inhibits reverse transcriptase, causing chain termination of viral DNA.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

ritonavir.definition: A protease inhibitor used as an antiretroviral agent and as a pharmacokinetic enhancer in HIV therapy.
ritonavir.mechanism: Inhibits HIV protease, preventing cleavage of viral polyproteins; strong CYP3A4 inhibitor.
indications: HIV-1 infection (as booster or in combination)

dosage.adults: 100-400 mg orally daily (as booster or in combination).

contraindications: Concomitant use with certain drugs (see label)

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

abacavir.definition: A nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used to treat HIV-1 infection.
abacavir.mechanism: Inhibits reverse transcriptase, causing chain termination of viral DNA.

dosage.adults: 600 mg orally once daily or 300 mg twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

methylene blue.definition: A dye and medication used to treat methemoglobinemia and as a diagnostic agent.
methylene blue.mechanism: Reduces methemoglobin to hemoglobin via NADPH-dependent pathway.

dosage.children: Same as adults, adjust by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid unless life-threatening.

bromocriptine.definition: A dopamine agonist used to treat Parkinson's disease, hyperprolactinemia, and acromegaly.
bromocriptine.mechanism: Stimulates dopamine receptors, inhibiting prolactin secretion and affecting motor control.

dosage.adults: 1.25-2.5 mg orally daily, titrate as needed.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

octreotide.definition: A somatostatin analog used to treat acromegaly, carcinoid tumors, and variceal bleeding.
octreotide.mechanism: Inhibits secretion of growth hormone, insulin, glucagon, and various GI peptides.

dosage.adults: 50-100 mcg SC 2-3 times daily; long-acting: 20 mg IM every 4 weeks.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

pegvisomant.definition: A growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat acromegaly.
pegvisomant.mechanism: Blocks growth hormone receptors, reducing IGF-1 production.

dosage.adults: 40 mg SC loading dose, then 10-30 mg SC once daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

lanreotide.definition: A somatostatin analog used to treat acromegaly and neuroendocrine tumors.
lanreotide.mechanism: Inhibits secretion of growth hormone and various GI peptides.

dosage.adults: 60-120 mg deep SC injection every 4 weeks.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

pasireotide.definition: A somatostatin analog used to treat Cushing's disease and acromegaly.
pasireotide.mechanism: Inhibits ACTH secretion, reducing cortisol production.

dosage.adults: 0.6-0.9 mg SC twice daily (Cushing's); 40 mg IM every 4 weeks (acromegaly).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

gabapentin.definition: An anticonvulsant and neuropathic pain agent.
gabapentin.mechanism: Binds to alpha-2-delta subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels, reducing excitatory neurotransmitter release.

dosage.adults: 300 mg once daily, titrate to 1800-3600 mg/day in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

fluorouracil.definition: A pyrimidine analog antimetabolite used to treat various cancers (topical for actinic keratosis and superficial basal cell carcinoma).
fluorouracil.mechanism: Inhibits thymidylate synthase, interfering with DNA synthesis.

dosage.adults: IV: 500-1000 mg/m² weekly; Topical: apply 1-2 times daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

aminolevulinic acid.definition: A photosensitizing agent used in photodynamic therapy for actinic keratosis.
aminolevulinic acid.mechanism: Converted to protoporphyrin IX, which produces reactive oxygen species upon light exposure, destroying abnormal cells.
indications: Actinic keratosis (in combination with photodynamic therapy)

dosage.adults: Topical: apply to lesion, then illuminate with blue light after 14-18 hours.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ingenol.definition: A topical agent (ingenol mebutate) used to treat actinic keratosis.
ingenol.mechanism: Induces cell death and promotes inflammatory response to destroy abnormal skin cells.

dosage.adults: Apply to affected area once daily for 2-3 consecutive days.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

amoxicillin.definition: A penicillin antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections.
amoxicillin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

penicillin g sodium.definition: A natural penicillin antibiotic used to treat serious bacterial infections.
penicillin g sodium.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

penicillin g potassium.definition: A natural penicillin antibiotic used to treat serious bacterial infections.
penicillin g potassium.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

albuterol.definition: A short-acting beta-2 agonist used as a bronchodilator for asthma and COPD.
albuterol.mechanism: Stimulates beta-2 adrenergic receptors, causing bronchial smooth muscle relaxation.

dosage.adults: 1-2 puffs (90-180 mcg) inhaled every 4-6 hours as needed.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

prednisolone.definition: A glucocorticoid used to treat inflammation, allergies, and autoimmune diseases.
prednisolone.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses by modulating gene expression.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

methylprednisolone.definition: A glucocorticoid used to treat inflammatory and autoimmune conditions, severe allergies, and as immunosuppression.
methylprednisolone.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses by modulating gene expression.

dosage.adults: 4-48 mg orally daily or IV/IM (dose individualized).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

epinephrine.definition: A sympathomimetic catecholamine used for anaphylaxis, cardiac arrest, and severe asthma exacerbations.
epinephrine.mechanism: Stimulates alpha and beta adrenergic receptors, causing vasoconstriction, increased heart rate, and bronchodilation.

dosage.adults: 0.3-0.5 mg IM (anaphylaxis); 1 mg IV every 3-5 min (cardiac arrest).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

hydrocortisone.definition: A glucocorticoid used for adrenal insufficiency, inflammation, and allergic conditions.
hydrocortisone.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses by modulating gene expression.

dosage.adults: 15-240 mg/day orally or IV/IM in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

theophylline.definition: A methylxanthine bronchodilator used for asthma and COPD.
theophylline.mechanism: Inhibits phosphodiesterase, increasing cAMP and causing bronchodilation.

dosage.adults: 300-600 mg/day in divided doses (dose individualized by serum levels).

special populations.pregnancy: Use with caution.

dexamethasone.definition: A potent glucocorticoid used for inflammatory and autoimmune conditions, cerebral edema, and as antiemetic in chemotherapy.
dexamethasone.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses by modulating gene expression.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

levalbuterol.definition: A short-acting beta-2 agonist bronchodilator used for asthma and COPD.
levalbuterol.mechanism: Stimulates beta-2 adrenergic receptors, causing bronchial smooth muscle relaxation.

dosage.adults: 0.63-1.25 mg nebulized every 6-8 hours as needed.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

terbutaline.definition: A beta-2 adrenergic agonist used as a bronchodilator for asthma and as a tocolytic.
terbutaline.mechanism: Stimulates beta-2 adrenergic receptors, causing bronchial and uterine smooth muscle relaxation.

dosage.adults: 2.5-5 mg orally three times daily; 0.25 mg SC every 20 min (max 3 doses).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ciprofloxacin.definition: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections.
ciprofloxacin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, preventing DNA replication.
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to ciprofloxacin or other quinolones

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid unless no alternatives.
special populations.children: Use only for specific serious infections.

nitrofurantoin.definition: A nitrofuran antibiotic used primarily for urinary tract infections.
nitrofurantoin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial enzymes involved in carbohydrate metabolism and cell wall synthesis.

dosage.adults: 100 mg orally twice daily for 5-7 days.

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid at term.

levofloxacin.definition: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections.
levofloxacin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, preventing DNA replication.

dosage.adults: 250-750 mg orally or IV once daily.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to levofloxacin or other quinolones

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid unless no alternatives.
special populations.children: Use only for specific serious infections.

ceftriaxone.definition: A third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat a wide range of bacterial infections.
ceftriaxone.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

clavulanate.definition: A beta-lactamase inhibitor used in combination with certain penicillins to extend their spectrum.
clavulanate.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial beta-lactamases, preventing antibiotic degradation.
indications: Used in combination with amoxicillin or ticarcillin for various infections

dosage.adults: See combination product (e.g., amoxicillin-clavulanate: 500/125 mg orally every 8-12 hours).

contraindications: History of cholestatic jaundice with clavulanate-containing products

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

cefuroxime.definition: A second-generation cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat various bacterial infections.
cefuroxime.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins.

dosage.adults: 250-500 mg orally twice daily or 750-1500 mg IV/IM every 8 hours.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

methenamine.definition: A urinary antiseptic used for prophylaxis and treatment of chronic urinary tract infections.
methenamine.mechanism: Hydrolyzed to formaldehyde in acidic urine, exerting antibacterial effects.
indications: Prophylaxis and treatment of chronic urinary tract infections

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ampicillin.definition: A penicillin antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections.
ampicillin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins.

dosage.adults: 250-500 mg orally every 6 hours; 1-2 g IV/IM every 4-6 hours.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

prednisone.definition: A glucocorticoid used to treat inflammation, allergies, and autoimmune diseases.
prednisone.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses by modulating gene expression.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

vincristine.definition: A vinca alkaloid chemotherapy agent used to treat various cancers including leukemia and lymphoma.
vincristine.mechanism: Inhibits microtubule formation in mitotic spindle, arresting cell division in metaphase.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by BSA.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

cyclophosphamide.definition: An alkylating agent used in chemotherapy and immunosuppression.
cyclophosphamide.mechanism: Alkylates DNA, causing cross-links and inhibiting DNA replication.

dosage.adults: 1-5 mg/kg/day orally or 40-50 mg/kg IV every 2-4 weeks.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

asparaginase escherichia coli.definition: An enzyme used in chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
asparaginase escherichia coli.mechanism: Depletes asparagine, an amino acid necessary for leukemia cell survival.

dosage.adults: 6,000-10,000 units/m² IM or IV every 3 days.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by BSA.

contraindications: History of severe hypersensitivity to asparaginase

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

daunorubicin.definition: An anthracycline antibiotic used as a chemotherapy agent for leukemia.
daunorubicin.mechanism: Intercalates DNA and inhibits topoisomerase II, causing DNA strand breaks.

dosage.adults: 30-60 mg/m² IV on days 1-3 of induction (protocol-specific).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

asparaginase erwinia chrysanthemi.definition: An enzyme used in chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), derived from Erwinia chrysanthemi.
asparaginase erwinia chrysanthemi.mechanism: Depletes asparagine, an amino acid necessary for leukemia cell survival.

dosage.adults: 25,000 units/m² IM or IV three times weekly.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by BSA.

contraindications: History of severe hypersensitivity to asparaginase

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

teniposide.definition: A podophyllotoxin derivative used in chemotherapy for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
teniposide.mechanism: Inhibits topoisomerase II, causing DNA strand breaks and inhibiting cell division.

dosage.adults: 165 mg/m² IV over 30-60 min once or twice weekly.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by BSA.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

clopidogrel.definition: An antiplatelet agent used to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
clopidogrel.mechanism: Inhibits ADP-induced platelet aggregation by irreversibly binding to the P2Y12 receptor.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ticagrelor.definition: A reversible P2Y12 receptor antagonist antiplatelet agent used to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
ticagrelor.mechanism: Reversibly inhibits ADP-induced platelet aggregation by binding to the P2Y12 receptor.

dosage.adults: 180 mg loading dose, then 90 mg orally twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

prasugrel.definition: An irreversible P2Y12 receptor antagonist antiplatelet agent used to reduce the risk of cardiovascular events.
prasugrel.mechanism: Irreversibly inhibits ADP-induced platelet aggregation by binding to the P2Y12 receptor.

dosage.adults: 60 mg loading dose, then 10 mg orally once daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

eptifibatide.definition: A glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor antiplatelet agent used in acute coronary syndrome and PCI.
eptifibatide.mechanism: Blocks glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor, inhibiting platelet aggregation.

dosage.adults: 180 mcg/kg IV bolus, then 2 mcg/kg/min infusion.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

tirofiban.definition: A glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitor antiplatelet agent used in acute coronary syndrome and PCI.
tirofiban.mechanism: Blocks glycoprotein IIb/IIIa receptor, inhibiting platelet aggregation.

dosage.adults: 25 mcg/kg IV bolus, then 0.15 mcg/kg/min infusion.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

azathioprine.definition: An immunosuppressant used to prevent organ rejection and treat autoimmune diseases.
azathioprine.mechanism: Inhibits purine synthesis, suppressing lymphocyte proliferation.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

penicillin g benzathine.definition: A long-acting penicillin antibiotic used to treat syphilis and rheumatic fever prophylaxis.
penicillin g benzathine.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

cytarabine.definition: A pyrimidine analog antimetabolite used in chemotherapy for leukemia and lymphoma.
cytarabine.mechanism: Inhibits DNA synthesis by acting as a cytosine analog.

dosage.adults: 100-200 mg/m²/day IV continuous infusion for 7 days (induction).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

idarubicin.definition: An anthracycline antibiotic used as a chemotherapy agent for leukemia.
idarubicin.mechanism: Intercalates DNA and inhibits topoisomerase II, causing DNA strand breaks.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

decitabine.definition: A hypomethylating agent used to treat myelodysplastic syndromes and acute myeloid leukemia.
decitabine.mechanism: Inhibits DNA methyltransferase, causing hypomethylation and reactivation of tumor suppressor genes.

dosage.adults: 20 mg/m² IV daily for 5 days every 4 weeks.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

gemtuzumab.definition: A monoclonal antibody-drug conjugate targeting CD33, used in acute myeloid leukemia.
gemtuzumab.mechanism: Binds to CD33 on leukemic cells, delivering cytotoxic agent calicheamicin.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by BSA.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

midostaurin.definition: A multi-kinase inhibitor used to treat FLT3-mutated acute myeloid leukemia and systemic mastocytosis.
midostaurin.mechanism: Inhibits multiple kinases including FLT3, KIT, and PDGFR.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

venetoclax.definition: A BCL-2 inhibitor used to treat chronic lymphocytic leukemia and acute myeloid leukemia.
venetoclax.mechanism: Inhibits BCL-2, promoting apoptosis in cancer cells.

dosage.adults: Start at 100 mg orally daily, titrate to 400-600 mg daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

enasidenib.definition: An IDH2 inhibitor used to treat relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia with IDH2 mutation.
enasidenib.mechanism: Inhibits mutant IDH2 enzyme, reducing 2-hydroxyglutarate and promoting cell differentiation.
indications: Relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia (IDH2 mutation)

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

cytarabine liposomal.definition: A liposomal formulation of cytarabine for intrathecal use in meningeal leukemia and lymphoma.
cytarabine liposomal.mechanism: Inhibits DNA synthesis by acting as a cytosine analog.
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to cytarabine or liposomal components

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

daunorubicin liposomal.definition: A liposomal formulation of daunorubicin used in combination with cytarabine for acute myeloid leukemia.
daunorubicin liposomal.mechanism: Intercalates DNA and inhibits topoisomerase II, causing DNA strand breaks.

dosage.adults: 44 mg/m² IV on days 1, 3, 5 (with cytarabine liposomal).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ivosidenib.definition: An IDH1 inhibitor used to treat relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia with IDH1 mutation.
ivosidenib.mechanism: Inhibits mutant IDH1 enzyme, reducing 2-hydroxyglutarate and promoting cell differentiation.
indications: Relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia (IDH1 mutation)

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

gilteritinib.definition: A FLT3 inhibitor used to treat relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia with FLT3 mutation.
gilteritinib.mechanism: Inhibits FLT3 tyrosine kinase, blocking proliferation of leukemic cells.
indications: Relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia (FLT3 mutation)

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

glasdegib.definition: A hedgehog pathway inhibitor used to treat newly diagnosed acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in adults who are not candidates for intensive chemotherapy.
glasdegib.mechanism: Inhibits the hedgehog signaling pathway by binding to Smoothened (SMO) receptor.
indications: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML), newly diagnosed, ineligible for intensive chemotherapy

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

chlorpromazine.definition: A typical antipsychotic used to treat psychotic disorders, nausea/vomiting, and intractable hiccups.
chlorpromazine.mechanism: Blocks dopamine D2 receptors in the brain; also has anticholinergic and antihistaminic effects.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

hemin.definition: A heme derivative used to treat acute attacks of porphyria.
hemin.mechanism: Inhibits delta-aminolevulinic acid synthase, reducing porphyrin synthesis.

dosage.adults: 3-4 mg/kg IV once daily for 3-14 days.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

givosiran.definition: A small interfering RNA (siRNA) used to treat acute hepatic porphyria.
givosiran.mechanism: Silences ALAS1 mRNA, reducing production of neurotoxic heme intermediates.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

mercaptopurine.definition: A purine antimetabolite used in the treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
mercaptopurine.mechanism: Inhibits purine synthesis, interfering with DNA and RNA synthesis.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

dasatinib.definition: A tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) with Philadelphia chromosome.
dasatinib.mechanism: Inhibits BCR-ABL and other tyrosine kinases.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

pegaspargase.definition: A pegylated form of L-asparaginase used in the treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
pegaspargase.mechanism: Depletes asparagine, an amino acid necessary for leukemia cell survival.

dosage.adults: 2,500 units/m² IM or IV every 2 weeks.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by BSA.

contraindications: History of severe hypersensitivity to pegaspargase

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

doxorubicin.definition: An anthracycline antibiotic used as a chemotherapy agent for various cancers.
doxorubicin.mechanism: Intercalates DNA and inhibits topoisomerase II, causing DNA strand breaks.

dosage.adults: 60-75 mg/m² IV every 21 days or 20-30 mg/m² weekly.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

imatinib.definition: A tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST).
imatinib.mechanism: Inhibits BCR-ABL, c-KIT, and PDGFR tyrosine kinases.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ponatinib.definition: A tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) and Philadelphia chromosome-positive ALL resistant to other therapies.
ponatinib.mechanism: Inhibits BCR-ABL and other kinases, including T315I mutant.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

vincristine liposome.definition: A liposomal formulation of vincristine used for Philadelphia chromosome-negative acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in adults.
vincristine liposome.mechanism: Inhibits microtubule formation in mitotic spindle, arresting cell division in metaphase.
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to vincristine or liposomal components

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

blinatumomab.definition: A bispecific T-cell engager antibody used to treat relapsed or refractory B-cell precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
blinatumomab.mechanism: Links CD19 on B cells to CD3 on T cells, promoting T-cell mediated cytotoxicity.
indications: Relapsed or refractory B-cell precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)

dosage.adults: 9 mcg/day IV continuous infusion for 7 days, then 28 mcg/day for 21 days (cycle-specific).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

thioguanine.definition: A purine antimetabolite used to treat acute myeloid leukemia (AML) and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).
thioguanine.mechanism: Inhibits purine synthesis, interfering with DNA and RNA synthesis.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

mitoxantrone.definition: An anthracenedione antineoplastic agent used to treat certain cancers and multiple sclerosis.
mitoxantrone.mechanism: Intercalates DNA and inhibits topoisomerase II, causing DNA strand breaks.

dosage.adults: 12 mg/m² IV every 21 days (cancer); 12 mg/m² IV every 3 months (MS).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ofloxacin.definition: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections.
ofloxacin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, preventing DNA replication.
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to ofloxacin or other quinolones

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid unless no alternatives.

colistin sulfate.definition: A polymyxin antibiotic used to treat infections caused by multidrug-resistant Gram-negative bacteria.
colistin sulfate.mechanism: Disrupts bacterial cell membrane by binding to phospholipids.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

neomycin.definition: An aminoglycoside antibiotic used topically and orally for bowel decontamination and hepatic encephalopathy.
neomycin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit.

dosage.adults: 1 g orally every 6-8 hours (short-term); Topical: apply as directed.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

thonzonium bromide.definition: A surfactant used in combination otic preparations to facilitate penetration and dispersion.
thonzonium bromide.mechanism: Acts as a surfactant to enhance penetration of other otic medications.
indications: Used in combination for otitis externa and otitis media

dosage.adults: As part of combination otic solutions, instill as directed.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.
special populations.children: Safe as part of combination products.

arsenic trioxide.definition: An antineoplastic agent used to treat acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).
arsenic trioxide.mechanism: Induces apoptosis and promotes differentiation of leukemic cells.

dosage.adults: 0.15 mg/kg IV daily until remission (up to 60 doses).
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

beractant.definition: A pulmonary surfactant used to prevent and treat respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in premature infants.
beractant.mechanism: Reduces surface tension in the alveoli, improving lung compliance.
indications: Prevention and treatment of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in premature infants

dosage.neonates: 100 mg/kg (4 mL/kg) intratracheally, up to 4 doses in 48 hours.

special populations.pregnancy: Not applicable (neonatal use).

poractant.definition: A natural surfactant extracted from porcine lungs, used to treat or prevent respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in premature infants.
poractant.mechanism: Reduces surface tension in the alveoli, improving lung compliance and oxygenation.
indications: Prevention and treatment of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in premature infants

dosage.neonates: Initial: 200 mg/kg (2.5 mL/kg) intratracheally; up to 2 repeat doses of 100 mg/kg at 12-hour intervals.

special populations.pregnancy: Not applicable (neonatal use).

calfactant.definition: A natural surfactant derived from calf lungs, used to treat or prevent respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in premature infants.
calfactant.mechanism: Reduces surface tension in the alveoli, improving lung compliance.
indications: Prevention and treatment of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) in premature infants

dosage.neonates: 3 mL/kg intratracheally; may repeat every 12 hours up to 3 doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Not applicable (neonatal use).

cefdinir.definition: A third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections.
cefdinir.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins.

dosage.adults: 300 mg orally every 12 hours for 5-10 days.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

azithromycin.definition: A macrolide antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections.
azithromycin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.

dosage.adults: 500 mg orally on day 1, then 250 mg once daily on days 2-5.
dosage.children: 10 mg/kg on day 1, then 5 mg/kg once daily on days 2-5.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

clarithromycin.definition: A macrolide antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections.
clarithromycin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.
contraindications: Concomitant use with certain statins or ergot derivatives

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

moxifloxacin.definition: A fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections.
moxifloxacin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, preventing DNA replication.

dosage.adults: 400 mg orally or IV once daily.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to moxifloxacin or other quinolones

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid unless no alternatives.

sertraline.definition: A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressant.
sertraline.mechanism: Inhibits reuptake of serotonin in the CNS, increasing serotonin levels.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

citalopram.definition: A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressant.
citalopram.mechanism: Inhibits reuptake of serotonin in the CNS, increasing serotonin levels.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

fluoxetine.definition: A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressant.
fluoxetine.mechanism: Inhibits reuptake of serotonin in the CNS, increasing serotonin levels.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

amitriptyline.definition: A tricyclic antidepressant used for depression and certain types of chronic pain.
amitriptyline.mechanism: Inhibits reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin in the CNS.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

venlafaxine.mechanism: Inhibits reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine in the CNS.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

paroxetine.definition: A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressant.
paroxetine.mechanism: Inhibits reuptake of serotonin in the CNS, increasing serotonin levels.

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid if possible (risk of fetal effects).

prazosin.definition: An alpha-1 adrenergic blocker used to treat hypertension and PTSD-related nightmares.
prazosin.mechanism: Blocks alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, causing vasodilation.

dosage.adults: 1-20 mg orally daily in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

fluvoxamine.definition: A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) used for obsessive-compulsive disorder and depression.
fluvoxamine.mechanism: Inhibits reuptake of serotonin in the CNS, increasing serotonin levels.

dosage.adults: 50-300 mg orally daily in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

pegademase bovine.definition: A pegylated bovine adenosine deaminase enzyme used to treat severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID) due to ADA deficiency.
pegademase bovine.mechanism: Replaces deficient adenosine deaminase, reducing toxic metabolites.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to pegademase or bovine proteins

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

elapegademase.definition: A recombinant pegylated adenosine deaminase enzyme used to treat ADA-SCID.
elapegademase.mechanism: Replaces deficient adenosine deaminase, reducing toxic metabolites.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ephedrine.definition: A sympathomimetic agent used for hypotension during anesthesia and as a bronchodilator.
ephedrine.mechanism: Stimulates alpha and beta adrenergic receptors, increasing blood pressure and cardiac output.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

isoproterenol.definition: A non-selective beta-adrenergic agonist used for bradyarrhythmias and heart block.
isoproterenol.mechanism: Stimulates beta-1 and beta-2 adrenergic receptors, increasing heart rate and causing bronchodilation.

dosage.adults: 2-10 mcg/min IV infusion, titrate to response.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

methylphenidate.definition: A CNS stimulant used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and narcolepsy.
methylphenidate.mechanism: Blocks reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine in the brain.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

amphetamine.definition: A CNS stimulant used to treat ADHD and narcolepsy.
amphetamine.mechanism: Promotes release of norepinephrine and dopamine from presynaptic neurons.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

dextroamphetamine.definition: A CNS stimulant used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and narcolepsy.
dextroamphetamine.mechanism: Promotes release of norepinephrine and dopamine from presynaptic neurons.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

clonidine.definition: An alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to treat hypertension, ADHD, and withdrawal symptoms.
clonidine.mechanism: Stimulates alpha-2 adrenergic receptors in the CNS, reducing sympathetic outflow.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

bupropion.definition: An atypical antidepressant used to treat depression, seasonal affective disorder, and for smoking cessation.
bupropion.mechanism: Inhibits reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine.

dosage.adults: 150-300 mg orally daily in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

guanfacine.definition: An alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to treat hypertension and ADHD.
guanfacine.mechanism: Stimulates alpha-2 adrenergic receptors in the CNS, reducing sympathetic outflow.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

lisdexamfetamine.definition: A CNS stimulant prodrug used to treat ADHD and binge eating disorder.
lisdexamfetamine.mechanism: Converted to dextroamphetamine, which increases norepinephrine and dopamine release.

dosage.adults: 30-70 mg orally once daily in the morning.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

atomoxetine.definition: A selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor used to treat ADHD.
atomoxetine.mechanism: Inhibits norepinephrine reuptake in the CNS.

dosage.adults: 40-100 mg orally once daily or divided twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

fludrocortisone.definition: A synthetic mineralocorticoid used to treat adrenocortical insufficiency and orthostatic hypotension.
fludrocortisone.mechanism: Increases sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion in the distal tubules.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

pazopanib.definition: A multi-tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat advanced renal cell carcinoma and soft tissue sarcoma.
pazopanib.mechanism: Inhibits VEGFR, PDGFR, and c-KIT tyrosine kinases.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

sunitinib.definition: A multi-tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat renal cell carcinoma and gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST).
sunitinib.mechanism: Inhibits VEGFR, PDGFR, and other kinases.

dosage.adults: 50 mg orally once daily for 4 weeks, then 2 weeks off (6-week cycle).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

axitinib.definition: A tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat advanced renal cell carcinoma.
indications: Advanced renal cell carcinoma (after failure of prior therapy)

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

nivolumab.definition: A PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibitor used to treat various cancers including melanoma, lung, and renal cell carcinoma.
nivolumab.mechanism: Blocks PD-1 receptor, enhancing T-cell mediated immune response against tumors.

dosage.adults: 240 mg IV every 2 weeks or 480 mg IV every 4 weeks.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

sorafenib.definition: A multi-kinase inhibitor used to treat advanced renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma, and thyroid cancer.
sorafenib.mechanism: Inhibits multiple kinases including RAF, VEGFR, and PDGFR.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

everolimus.definition: An mTOR inhibitor used to treat various cancers and prevent organ transplant rejection.
everolimus.mechanism: Inhibits mTOR, suppressing cell proliferation and angiogenesis.

dosage.adults: 10 mg orally once daily (cancer); 0.75 mg twice daily (transplant).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

bevacizumab.definition: A monoclonal antibody against VEGF used to treat various cancers and some eye diseases.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

cabozantinib.definition: A multi-tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma, and medullary thyroid cancer.
cabozantinib.mechanism: Inhibits MET, VEGFR2, and other kinases.

dosage.adults: 60 mg orally once daily (RCC/HCC); 140 mg once daily (thyroid).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

aldesleukin.definition: A recombinant interleukin-2 (IL-2) used to treat metastatic renal cell carcinoma and metastatic melanoma.
aldesleukin.mechanism: Stimulates proliferation and activation of lymphocytes.

dosage.adults: 600,000 IU/kg IV every 8 hours for up to 14 doses per cycle.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

capecitabine.definition: An oral prodrug of 5-fluorouracil used to treat breast and colorectal cancer.
capecitabine.mechanism: Converted to 5-FU, which inhibits thymidylate synthase and DNA synthesis.

dosage.adults: 1,250 mg/m² orally twice daily for 14 days, then 7 days off (21-day cycle).

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

temsirolimus.definition: An mTOR inhibitor used to treat advanced renal cell carcinoma.
temsirolimus.mechanism: Inhibits mTOR, suppressing cell proliferation and angiogenesis.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

lenvatinib.definition: A multi-tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat thyroid cancer, renal cell carcinoma, and hepatocellular carcinoma.
lenvatinib.mechanism: Inhibits VEGFR, FGFR, PDGFR, RET, and KIT kinases.

dosage.adults: 8-24 mg orally once daily, depending on indication.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

adenovirus vaccine.definition: A live, oral vaccine used to prevent febrile acute respiratory disease caused by adenovirus types 4 and 7, primarily in military populations.
adenovirus vaccine.mechanism: Induces immunity against adenovirus types 4 and 7.
indications: Prevention of adenovirus types 4 and 7 infection (military personnel)

dosage.adults: One dose (two tablets: type 4 and type 7) orally, as a single dose.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

piroxicam.definition: A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for pain and inflammation in osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis.
piroxicam.mechanism: Inhibits cyclooxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2), reducing prostaglandin synthesis.
contraindications: History of asthma, urticaria, or allergic-type reactions after NSAIDs

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in third trimester.

triamcinolone.definition: A glucocorticoid used to treat inflammation, allergies, and certain skin conditions.
triamcinolone.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses by modulating gene expression.

dosage.adults: Topical: apply as directed; IM: 40-80 mg as a single dose; intra-articular: 2.5-40 mg per joint.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

fentanyl.definition: A potent synthetic opioid analgesic used for severe pain and anesthesia.
fentanyl.mechanism: Binds to mu-opioid receptors in the CNS, altering pain perception.

dosage.adults: IV: 25-100 mcg/dose; transdermal: 12-100 mcg/hr patch every 72 hours.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

pregabalin.definition: An anticonvulsant and neuropathic pain agent.
pregabalin.mechanism: Binds to alpha-2-delta subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels, reducing neurotransmitter release.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

probenecid.definition: A uricosuric agent used to treat gout and prolong the action of certain antibiotics.
probenecid.mechanism: Inhibits renal tubular reabsorption of uric acid, increasing its excretion.

dosage.adults: 250 mg orally twice daily, may increase to 500-1000 mg twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

enalapril.definition: An angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor used to treat hypertension and heart failure.
enalapril.mechanism: Inhibits ACE, decreasing angiotensin II production and lowering blood pressure.

dosage.adults: 5-40 mg orally once or twice daily.

contraindications: History of angioedema with ACE inhibitors

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

lisinopril.definition: An ACE inhibitor used to treat hypertension, heart failure, and post-myocardial infarction.
lisinopril.mechanism: Inhibits ACE, decreasing angiotensin II production and lowering blood pressure.
contraindications: History of angioedema with ACE inhibitors

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

captopril.definition: An ACE inhibitor used to treat hypertension, heart failure, and diabetic nephropathy.
captopril.mechanism: Inhibits ACE, decreasing angiotensin II production and lowering blood pressure.
contraindications: History of angioedema with ACE inhibitors

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

mitotane.definition: An adrenolytic agent used to treat inoperable adrenocortical carcinoma.
mitotane.mechanism: Destroys adrenocortical cells, reducing cortisol production.

dosage.adults: 2-6 g orally daily in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

cortisone.definition: A glucocorticoid used for adrenal insufficiency and inflammatory conditions.
cortisone.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses by modulating gene expression.

dosage.adults: 25-300 mg orally or IM daily in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

cosyntropin.definition: A synthetic ACTH analog used as a diagnostic agent for adrenal insufficiency.
cosyntropin.mechanism: Stimulates the adrenal cortex to secrete cortisol, aldosterone, and androgens.
indications: Diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency (ACTH stimulation test)

dosage.adults: 250 mcg IV or IM as a single dose.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

somatropin.definition: A recombinant human growth hormone used to treat growth hormone deficiency and certain growth disorders.
somatropin.mechanism: Stimulates growth, cell reproduction, and regeneration.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

anakinra.definition: An interleukin-1 receptor antagonist used to treat rheumatoid arthritis and cryopyrin-associated periodic syndromes.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

tocilizumab.definition: An interleukin-6 receptor antagonist used to treat rheumatoid arthritis and cytokine release syndrome.

dosage.adults: 4-8 mg/kg IV every 4 weeks or 162 mg SC every week.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

etanercept.definition: A tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor used to treat autoimmune diseases.
etanercept.mechanism: Binds TNF-alpha, preventing its interaction with cell surface receptors.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

digoxin.definition: A cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure and atrial fibrillation.
digoxin.mechanism: Inhibits Na+/K+-ATPase, increasing intracellular calcium and cardiac contractility.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

diltiazem.definition: A non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker used for hypertension, angina, and arrhythmias.
diltiazem.mechanism: Inhibits calcium influx into cardiac and vascular smooth muscle, reducing contractility and conduction.

dosage.adults: 120-360 mg orally daily in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

flecainide.definition: A class Ic antiarrhythmic used to treat and prevent certain types of serious arrhythmias.
flecainide.mechanism: Blocks sodium channels, slowing conduction in cardiac tissue.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

sotalol.definition: A non-selective beta blocker and class III antiarrhythmic used to treat and prevent arrhythmias.
sotalol.mechanism: Blocks beta-adrenergic receptors and prolongs cardiac action potential.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

propafenone.definition: A class Ic antiarrhythmic used to treat and prevent certain types of serious arrhythmias.
propafenone.mechanism: Blocks sodium channels, slowing conduction in cardiac tissue.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

rivaroxaban.definition: An oral direct factor Xa inhibitor anticoagulant.
rivaroxaban.mechanism: Inhibits factor Xa, preventing thrombin generation and clot formation.

dosage.adults: 10-20 mg orally once daily (dose depends on indication).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

dronedarone.definition: A class III antiarrhythmic used to reduce the risk of hospitalization in patients with paroxysmal or persistent atrial fibrillation.
dronedarone.mechanism: Blocks multiple cardiac ion channels, prolonging action potential and refractory period.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

propranolol.definition: A non-selective beta blocker used for hypertension, angina, arrhythmias, migraine prophylaxis, and anxiety.
propranolol.mechanism: Blocks beta-1 and beta-2 adrenergic receptors, reducing heart rate and blood pressure.

dosage.adults: 40-320 mg orally daily in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

pentamidine.definition: An antiprotozoal and antifungal agent used to treat Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia and leishmaniasis.
pentamidine.mechanism: Inhibits DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis in susceptible organisms.

dosage.adults: 4 mg/kg IV or IM once daily for 14-21 days.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

benznidazole.definition: An antiprotozoal agent used to treat Chagas disease (Trypanosoma cruzi infection).
