benznidazole.mechanism: Produces free radicals that damage DNA and proteins in parasites.

dosage.adults: 5-7 mg/kg/day orally in 2 divided doses for 60 days.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid unless no alternatives.

haloperidol.definition: A typical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia, acute psychosis, and Tourette syndrome.
haloperidol.mechanism: Blocks dopamine D2 receptors in the brain.

dosage.adults: 2-20 mg orally daily in divided doses; IM/IV for acute agitation.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.
special populations.elderly: Increased risk of mortality in dementia-related psychosis.

aripiprazole.definition: An atypical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and depression (adjunct).
aripiprazole.mechanism: Partial agonist at dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT1A receptors; antagonist at 5-HT2A.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.
special populations.elderly: Increased risk of mortality in dementia-related psychosis.

olanzapine.definition: An atypical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.
olanzapine.mechanism: Antagonist at dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2A receptors.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.
special populations.elderly: Increased risk of mortality in dementia-related psychosis.

loxapine.definition: A typical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia and acute agitation.
loxapine.mechanism: Blocks dopamine D2 receptors in the brain.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.
special populations.elderly: Increased risk of mortality in dementia-related psychosis.

risperidone.definition: An atypical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and irritability in autism.
risperidone.mechanism: Antagonist at dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2A receptors.

dosage.adults: 1-8 mg orally once or twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.
special populations.elderly: Increased risk of mortality in dementia-related psychosis.

perphenazine.definition: A typical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia and severe nausea/vomiting.
perphenazine.mechanism: Blocks dopamine D2 receptors in the brain.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.
special populations.elderly: Increased risk of mortality in dementia-related psychosis.

ruxolitinib.definition: A Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitor used to treat myelofibrosis, polycythemia vera, and graft-versus-host disease.
ruxolitinib.mechanism: Inhibits JAK1 and JAK2, reducing cytokine and growth factor signaling.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

fedratinib.definition: A Janus kinase 2 (JAK2) inhibitor used to treat myelofibrosis.
fedratinib.mechanism: Inhibits JAK2, reducing abnormal blood cell production.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

filgrastim.definition: A granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) used to reduce the risk of infection in neutropenic patients.
filgrastim.mechanism: Stimulates production of neutrophils in the bone marrow.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to filgrastim or E. coli-derived proteins

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

dronabinol.definition: A synthetic form of THC used to treat chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting and appetite loss in AIDS.
dronabinol.mechanism: Activates cannabinoid receptors in the CNS.
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to sesame oil or cannabinoids

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

naltrexone.definition: An opioid antagonist used to treat alcohol and opioid dependence.
naltrexone.mechanism: Blocks opioid receptors, reducing the effects of opioids and alcohol.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

acamprosate.definition: A medication used to maintain abstinence in alcohol-dependent patients.
acamprosate.mechanism: Modulates glutamatergic neurotransmission in the CNS.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

disulfiram.definition: A medication used to support the treatment of chronic alcoholism by producing an acute sensitivity to ethanol.
disulfiram.mechanism: Inhibits aldehyde dehydrogenase, causing unpleasant effects when alcohol is consumed.
contraindications: Concurrent use of alcohol or metronidazole

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ondansetron.definition: A selective 5-HT3 receptor antagonist used to prevent and treat nausea and vomiting.
ondansetron.mechanism: Blocks serotonin (5-HT3) receptors in the CNS and GI tract.

dosage.adults: 4-8 mg orally or IV every 8 hours as needed.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

gabapentin enacarbil.definition: A prodrug of gabapentin used to treat restless legs syndrome and postherpetic neuralgia.
gabapentin enacarbil.mechanism: Converted to gabapentin, which binds to alpha-2-delta subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels.

dosage.adults: 600 mg orally once or twice daily.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to gabapentin enacarbil or gabapentin

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

baclofen.definition: A muscle relaxant used to treat spasticity from multiple sclerosis and spinal cord injuries.
baclofen.mechanism: Activates GABA-B receptors, inhibiting synaptic transmission in the spinal cord.
indications: Spasticity due to multiple sclerosis or spinal cord injury

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

chlordiazepoxide.definition: A benzodiazepine used to treat anxiety, alcohol withdrawal, and preoperative sedation.
chlordiazepoxide.mechanism: Enhances the effect of GABA at the GABA-A receptor, producing CNS depression.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

oxazepam.definition: A benzodiazepine used to treat anxiety and alcohol withdrawal.
oxazepam.mechanism: Enhances the effect of GABA at the GABA-A receptor, producing CNS depression.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

clorazepate.definition: A benzodiazepine used to treat anxiety, alcohol withdrawal, and as adjunct in seizure disorders.
clorazepate.mechanism: Enhances the effect of GABA at the GABA-A receptor, producing CNS depression.

dosage.adults: 15-60 mg orally daily in divided doses.
dosage.children: 0.5-1 mg/kg/day in divided doses (seizures, age ≥9 years).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

propylthiouracil.definition: An antithyroid agent used to treat hyperthyroidism and Graves' disease.
propylthiouracil.mechanism: Inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis and peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.

special populations.pregnancy: Preferred in first trimester.

oxandrolone.definition: An anabolic steroid used to promote weight gain after weight loss and to offset protein catabolism.
oxandrolone.mechanism: Promotes protein synthesis and muscle growth.

dosage.adults: 2.5-20 mg orally daily in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

hydroxyquinoline.definition: A topical antiseptic and antifungal agent (also known as clioquinol).
hydroxyquinoline.mechanism: Chelates metal ions and disrupts microbial enzyme systems.

dosage.adults: Apply to affected area 2-3 times daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ammonium chloride.definition: An expectorant and systemic acidifying agent.
ammonium chloride.mechanism: Increases acidity of body fluids and stimulates respiratory tract secretions.

dosage.adults: 1-2 g orally 3-4 times daily (alkalosis); as directed in cough syrups.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

salmeterol.definition: A long-acting beta-2 agonist bronchodilator used for asthma and COPD maintenance therapy.
salmeterol.mechanism: Stimulates beta-2 adrenergic receptors, causing bronchial smooth muscle relaxation.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ketotifen.definition: An antihistamine and mast cell stabilizer used for allergic conjunctivitis and asthma prophylaxis (non-U.S.).
ketotifen.mechanism: Blocks histamine H1 receptors and stabilizes mast cells.

dosage.adults: Ophthalmic: 1 drop in affected eye(s) twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

azelastine.definition: A second-generation antihistamine used for allergic rhinitis and allergic conjunctivitis.

dosage.adults: Nasal: 1-2 sprays per nostril twice daily; Ophthalmic: 1 drop in each eye twice daily.
dosage.children: Same as adults (age 6+ for nasal, age 3+ for ophthalmic).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

cromolyn.definition: A mast cell stabilizer used for asthma prophylaxis and allergic conditions.
cromolyn.mechanism: Prevents mast cell degranulation, inhibiting the release of histamine and other mediators.

dosage.adults: Inhaled: 20 mg 4 times daily; Nasal: 1 spray per nostril 3-4 times daily; Ophthalmic: 1-2 drops in each eye 4-6 times daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

epinastine.definition: A second-generation antihistamine and mast cell stabilizer for allergic conjunctivitis.
epinastine.mechanism: Blocks histamine H1 receptors and stabilizes mast cells.

dosage.adults: 1 drop in each eye twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

nedocromil.definition: A mast cell stabilizer used for allergic conjunctivitis and formerly for asthma prophylaxis.
nedocromil.mechanism: Prevents mast cell degranulation, inhibiting the release of histamine and other mediators.

dosage.adults: 1-2 drops in each eye twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

bepotastine.definition: A second-generation antihistamine used for allergic conjunctivitis.

dosage.adults: 1 drop in each eye twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

cetirizine.definition: A second-generation antihistamine used to treat allergic rhinitis and urticaria.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

alcaftadine.definition: A second-generation antihistamine used for allergic conjunctivitis.

dosage.adults: 1 drop in each eye once daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

carbinoxamine.definition: A first-generation antihistamine used to treat allergic conditions and as a sedative.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

doxylamine.definition: A first-generation antihistamine used as a short-term sleep aid and for allergy symptoms.
indications: Nausea and vomiting in pregnancy (with pyridoxine)

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe for NVP.

clobetasol.definition: A super-high potency topical corticosteroid used for inflammatory and pruritic skin disorders.
clobetasol.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses in the skin.

dosage.adults: Apply thin layer to affected area twice daily for up to 2 weeks.
dosage.children: Use with caution; not recommended for children <12 years.

contraindications: Viral, fungal, or tubercular skin infections

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.
special populations.children: Use with caution and for short duration.

betamethasone.definition: A potent glucocorticoid used to treat inflammation, allergies, and certain skin conditions.
betamethasone.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses by modulating gene expression.

dosage.adults: Topical: apply as directed; IM: 12 mg for 2 doses 24 hours apart (antenatal).

special populations.pregnancy: Antenatal use for fetal lung maturity.

fluocinonide.definition: A high-potency topical corticosteroid used for inflammatory and pruritic skin disorders.
fluocinonide.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses in the skin.

dosage.adults: Apply thin layer to affected area 2-4 times daily.
dosage.children: Use with caution; not recommended for children <12 years.

contraindications: Viral, fungal, or tubercular skin infections

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.
special populations.children: Use with caution and for short duration.

tacrolimus.definition: A calcineurin inhibitor immunosuppressant used for organ transplantation and as a topical agent for eczema.
tacrolimus.mechanism: Inhibits calcineurin, reducing T-cell activation and cytokine production.

dosage.adults: Oral: 0.1-0.2 mg/kg/day in 2 divided doses; Topical: apply thin layer twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

mometasone.definition: A medium- to high-potency corticosteroid used for allergic rhinitis, asthma, and skin inflammation.

dosage.adults: Nasal: 2 sprays per nostril once daily; Inhaled: 220 mcg once daily; Topical: apply thin layer once daily.
dosage.children: Dosing varies by indication and age.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

desonide.definition: A low-potency topical corticosteroid used for mild inflammatory skin conditions.
desonide.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses in the skin.

dosage.adults: Apply thin layer to affected area 2-4 times daily.
dosage.children: Safe for use in children ≥3 months.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

fluocinolone.definition: A low- to medium-potency topical corticosteroid used for inflammatory and pruritic skin disorders.
fluocinolone.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses in the skin.

dosage.adults: Apply thin layer to affected area 2-4 times daily.
dosage.children: Use with caution; safe for pediatric eczema.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

desoximetasone.definition: A high-potency topical corticosteroid used for inflammatory and pruritic skin disorders.
desoximetasone.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses in the skin.

dosage.adults: Apply thin layer to affected area twice daily.
dosage.children: Use with caution; not recommended for children <12 years.

contraindications: Viral, fungal, or tubercular skin infections

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.
special populations.children: Use with caution and for short duration.

fluticasone.definition: A corticosteroid used for asthma, allergic rhinitis, and skin inflammation.

dosage.adults: Inhaled: 100-500 mcg twice daily; Nasal: 1-2 sprays per nostril once daily; Topical: apply thin layer once or twice daily.
dosage.children: Dosing varies by indication and age.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

diphenhydramine.definition: A first-generation antihistamine used for allergy symptoms, insomnia, and motion sickness.

dosage.adults: 25-50 mg orally every 4-6 hours as needed.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

loratadine.definition: A second-generation antihistamine used to treat allergy symptoms.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

chlorpheniramine.definition: A first-generation antihistamine used for allergy symptoms and cold relief.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

promethazine.definition: A first-generation antihistamine with antiemetic and sedative properties.
promethazine.mechanism: Blocks histamine H1 receptors and dopamine receptors.

dosage.adults: 12.5-25 mg orally or IM every 4-6 hours as needed.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.
special populations.children: Avoid in <2 years due to respiratory depression risk.

cyproheptadine.definition: A first-generation antihistamine with antiserotonergic and appetite-stimulating properties.
cyproheptadine.mechanism: Blocks histamine H1 and serotonin receptors.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

montelukast.definition: A leukotriene receptor antagonist used for asthma maintenance and allergic rhinitis.
montelukast.mechanism: Blocks leukotriene D4 receptors in the airways.

dosage.adults: 10 mg orally once daily in the evening.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

fexofenadine.definition: A second-generation antihistamine used to treat allergy symptoms.

dosage.adults: 60 mg orally twice daily or 180 mg once daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

levocetirizine.definition: A second-generation antihistamine used to treat allergy symptoms.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

hydroxyzine.definition: A first-generation antihistamine used for anxiety, pruritus, and as a sedative.

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in early pregnancy.

triprolidine.definition: A first-generation antihistamine used for allergy symptoms and cold relief.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

tetracaine.definition: A local anesthetic used for topical anesthesia of the eye, skin, and mucous membranes.
tetracaine.mechanism: Blocks sodium channels, inhibiting nerve impulse conduction.

dosage.adults: Ophthalmic: 1-2 drops as needed; Topical: apply as directed.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to tetracaine or ester anesthetics

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

corticotropin.definition: A polypeptide hormone used as a diagnostic agent and to treat certain inflammatory conditions.
corticotropin.mechanism: Stimulates the adrenal cortex to secrete cortisol, aldosterone, and androgens.

dosage.adults: 80-120 units IM daily for 2-3 weeks (MS exacerbation).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

dexbrompheniramine.definition: A first-generation antihistamine used for allergy symptoms and cold relief.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

phenylephrine.definition: An alpha-1 adrenergic agonist used as a decongestant, vasopressor, and mydriatic.
phenylephrine.mechanism: Stimulates alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, causing vasoconstriction.

dosage.adults: 10 mg orally every 4 hours (decongestant); IV: 0.1-0.5 mg as needed.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

minoxidil.definition: A vasodilator used orally for severe hypertension and topically for androgenetic alopecia.
minoxidil.mechanism: Opens potassium channels in vascular smooth muscle, causing vasodilation.

dosage.adults: Oral: 2.5-80 mg daily in divided doses; Topical: apply 1 mL to scalp twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.
special populations.children: Oral use for severe hypertension only.

sulfasalazine.definition: A sulfonamide and salicylate derivative used to treat rheumatoid arthritis and inflammatory bowel disease.
sulfasalazine.mechanism: Inhibits prostaglandin synthesis and modulates immune response.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

hydroxyurea.definition: An antimetabolite used to treat sickle cell disease, chronic myeloid leukemia, and other cancers.
hydroxyurea.mechanism: Inhibits ribonucleotide reductase, blocking DNA synthesis.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.
special populations.children: Indicated for pediatric sickle cell disease.

deferasirox.definition: An oral iron chelator used to treat chronic iron overload due to blood transfusions.
deferasirox.mechanism: Binds iron, allowing its excretion in the feces.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

deferiprone.definition: An oral iron chelator used to treat transfusional iron overload in thalassemia syndromes.
deferiprone.mechanism: Binds iron, allowing its excretion in the urine.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

alpha 1-proteinase inhibitor.definition: A plasma-derived protein used to treat alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.
alpha 1-proteinase inhibitor.mechanism: Inhibits neutrophil elastase, protecting lung tissue.
contraindications: Selective IgA deficiency with antibodies to IgA

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

losartan.definition: An angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) used to treat hypertension, heart failure, and diabetic nephropathy.
losartan.mechanism: Blocks angiotensin II type 1 receptors, lowering blood pressure.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

fosinopril.definition: An ACE inhibitor used to treat hypertension and heart failure.
fosinopril.mechanism: Inhibits ACE, decreasing angiotensin II production and lowering blood pressure.
contraindications: History of angioedema with ACE inhibitors

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

candesartan.definition: An angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) used to treat hypertension and heart failure.
candesartan.mechanism: Blocks angiotensin II type 1 receptors, lowering blood pressure.

dosage.children: 4-16 mg once daily (age 1+; dose by weight).

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

quinapril.definition: An ACE inhibitor used to treat hypertension and heart failure.
quinapril.mechanism: Inhibits ACE, decreasing angiotensin II production and lowering blood pressure.

dosage.adults: 10-80 mg orally once or twice daily.

contraindications: History of angioedema with ACE inhibitors

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

riluzole.definition: A glutamate antagonist used to slow disease progression in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
riluzole.mechanism: Inhibits glutamate release, inactivates voltage-dependent sodium channels.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

edaravone.definition: A free radical scavenger used to slow functional decline in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
edaravone.mechanism: Reduces oxidative stress by scavenging free radicals.

dosage.adults: 60 mg IV over 60 minutes daily for 14 days, then 14-day drug-free period (cycle repeats).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

trabectedin.definition: An antineoplastic agent used to treat unresectable or metastatic liposarcoma or leiomyosarcoma.
trabectedin.mechanism: Binds to DNA minor groove, disrupting cell division.

dosage.adults: 1.5 mg/m² IV over 24 hours every 3 weeks.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

olaratumab.definition: A monoclonal antibody that targets PDGFR-alpha, previously used for soft tissue sarcoma.
indications: Soft tissue sarcoma (withdrawn from market in some regions)

dosage.adults: 15 mg/kg IV on days 1 and 8 of a 21-day cycle.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

donepezil.definition: A cholinesterase inhibitor used to treat Alzheimer's disease.
donepezil.mechanism: Inhibits acetylcholinesterase, increasing acetylcholine in the CNS.

dosage.adults: 5-10 mg orally once daily (max 23 mg/day for severe).

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to donepezil or piperidine derivatives

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

memantine.definition: An NMDA receptor antagonist used to treat moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease.
memantine.mechanism: Blocks NMDA glutamate receptors, reducing excitotoxicity.

dosage.adults: 5-20 mg orally once daily or divided twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

galantamine.definition: A cholinesterase inhibitor used to treat mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease.
galantamine.mechanism: Inhibits acetylcholinesterase and modulates nicotinic receptors.

dosage.adults: 16-24 mg orally once daily (extended-release) or divided twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

rivastigmine.definition: A cholinesterase inhibitor used to treat mild to moderate Alzheimer's and Parkinson's dementia.

dosage.adults: 6-12 mg orally daily in divided doses or 4.6-13.3 mg/24h transdermal patch.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

vitamin e.definition: A fat-soluble vitamin with antioxidant properties.
vitamin e.mechanism: Protects cell membranes from oxidative damage.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

ergoloid mesylates.definition: A mixture of ergot alkaloids used to treat cognitive impairment and dementia.
ergoloid mesylates.mechanism: Enhances cerebral metabolism and neurotransmitter activity.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

tinidazole.definition: A nitroimidazole antibiotic used to treat protozoal and anaerobic bacterial infections.
tinidazole.mechanism: Disrupts DNA synthesis in susceptible organisms.

dosage.adults: 2 g orally once daily for 1-3 days.

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in first trimester.

nitazoxanide.definition: An antiprotozoal and antiviral agent used to treat diarrhea caused by Giardia or Cryptosporidium.
nitazoxanide.mechanism: Interferes with anaerobic energy metabolism by inhibiting pyruvate:ferredoxin oxidoreductase.
indications: Diarrhea caused by Giardia lamblia or Cryptosporidium parvum

dosage.adults: 500 mg orally every 12 hours for 3 days.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

paromomycin.definition: An aminoglycoside antibiotic used to treat intestinal amebiasis and tapeworm infections.
paromomycin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit.

dosage.adults: 25-35 mg/kg/day orally in 3 divided doses for 5-10 days.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

chloroquine.definition: An antimalarial and anti-inflammatory agent used to treat malaria and autoimmune diseases.
chloroquine.mechanism: Inhibits heme polymerase in Plasmodium and modulates immune response.

dosage.adults: 1 g orally, then 500 mg at 6, 24, and 48 hours (malaria); 250-500 mg daily (RA/lupus).
dosage.children: 10 mg/kg, then 5 mg/kg at 6, 24, and 48 hours.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

progesterone.definition: A natural progestin hormone used in hormone replacement, contraception, and infertility.
progesterone.mechanism: Binds to progesterone receptors, regulating gene expression.

special populations.pregnancy: Indicated for luteal support.

tafamidis.definition: A transthyretin stabilizer used to treat transthyretin-mediated amyloidosis.
tafamidis.mechanism: Stabilizes transthyretin tetramer, preventing amyloid fibril formation.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

inotersen.definition: An antisense oligonucleotide used to treat hereditary transthyretin-mediated amyloidosis.
inotersen.mechanism: Inhibits hepatic production of transthyretin protein.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

patisiran.definition: A small interfering RNA (siRNA) used to treat hereditary transthyretin-mediated amyloidosis.
patisiran.mechanism: Silences transthyretin mRNA, reducing protein production.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

colchicine.definition: An anti-inflammatory agent used to treat and prevent gout flares and familial Mediterranean fever.
colchicine.mechanism: Inhibits microtubule polymerization, reducing neutrophil activity.

dosage.adults: 1.2 mg orally at first sign of flare, then 0.6 mg 1 hour later (max 1.8 mg per flare).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

piperacillin.definition: An extended-spectrum penicillin antibiotic used to treat serious bacterial infections.
piperacillin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

tazobactam.definition: A beta-lactamase inhibitor used in combination with piperacillin.
tazobactam.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial beta-lactamases, extending the spectrum of piperacillin.
indications: Used in combination with piperacillin for serious infections

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

sulbactam.definition: A beta-lactamase inhibitor used in combination with ampicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics.
sulbactam.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial beta-lactamases, extending the spectrum of beta-lactam antibiotics.
indications: Used in combination with ampicillin or other beta-lactams for serious infections

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

cefoxitin.definition: A second-generation cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat a variety of bacterial infections.
cefoxitin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

cilastatin.definition: A renal dehydropeptidase inhibitor used in combination with imipenem to prevent its degradation.
cilastatin.mechanism: Inhibits renal dehydropeptidase I, preventing imipenem breakdown.
indications: Used in combination with imipenem for serious infections

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

imipenem.definition: A broad-spectrum carbapenem antibiotic used to treat serious bacterial infections.
imipenem.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

mitomycin.definition: An antineoplastic antibiotic used to treat various cancers and as an intravesical agent for bladder cancer.
mitomycin.mechanism: Alkylates DNA, causing cross-links and inhibiting DNA synthesis.

dosage.adults: 10-20 mg/m² IV every 6-8 weeks; intravesical: 20-40 mg once weekly.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

cisplatin.definition: A platinum-based chemotherapy agent used to treat various cancers.
cisplatin.mechanism: Forms DNA cross-links, inhibiting DNA synthesis and function.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

lidocaine.definition: A local anesthetic and class Ib antiarrhythmic agent.
lidocaine.mechanism: Blocks sodium channels, inhibiting nerve impulse conduction and cardiac depolarization.

dosage.adults: Arrhythmia: 1-1.5 mg/kg IV bolus, then infusion; Local: apply as directed.

contraindications: Severe SA, AV, or intraventricular block (arrhythmia use)

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

zinc oxide.definition: A topical skin protectant and mild astringent.
zinc oxide.mechanism: Forms a protective barrier on the skin.

dosage.adults: Apply to affected area as needed.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

benzocaine.definition: A local anesthetic used topically for pain relief.
benzocaine.mechanism: Blocks sodium channels, inhibiting nerve impulse conduction.

dosage.adults: Apply to affected area up to 4 times daily.
dosage.children: Use with caution; avoid in children <2 years.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

temozolomide.definition: An oral alkylating agent used to treat glioblastoma multiforme and anaplastic astrocytoma.

dosage.adults: 150-200 mg/m² orally once daily for 5 days every 28 days.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

procarbazine.definition: An oral alkylating agent used to treat Hodgkin lymphoma and brain tumors.
procarbazine.mechanism: Inhibits DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

lomustine.definition: An oral alkylating agent used to treat brain tumors and Hodgkin lymphoma.
lomustine.mechanism: Alkylates DNA and RNA, inhibiting synthesis.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

thyroid desiccated.definition: A natural thyroid hormone product containing T3 and T4, used to treat hypothyroidism.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

sodium iodide-i-131.definition: A radioactive iodine isotope used to treat hyperthyroidism and thyroid cancer.
sodium iodide-i-131.mechanism: Concentrates in thyroid tissue, emitting beta and gamma radiation to destroy cells.

dosage.adults: Dose individualized by indication and uptake studies.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

thyrotropin alpha.definition: A recombinant human thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) used in diagnostic testing and thyroid cancer management.
thyrotropin alpha.mechanism: Stimulates thyroid tissue to uptake radioactive iodine.
indications: Adjunct in thyroid cancer diagnostics and therapy

dosage.adults: 0.9 mg IM once daily for 2 days.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

vandetanib.definition: A tyrosine kinase inhibitor used to treat medullary thyroid cancer.
vandetanib.mechanism: Inhibits VEGFR, EGFR, and RET tyrosine kinases.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

dabrafenib.definition: A BRAF kinase inhibitor used to treat BRAF V600E mutation-positive cancers.
dabrafenib.mechanism: Inhibits mutant BRAF kinase, blocking MAPK pathway activation.
indications: Non-small cell lung cancer (BRAF V600E mutation)

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

trametinib.definition: A MEK inhibitor used to treat BRAF V600 mutation-positive cancers.
trametinib.mechanism: Inhibits MEK1 and MEK2, blocking MAPK pathway activation.
indications: Non-small cell lung cancer (BRAF V600 mutation)

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

mebendazole.definition: A broad-spectrum antihelminthic agent used to treat intestinal worm infections.

dosage.adults: 100 mg orally twice daily for 3 days or 500 mg single dose (depending on infection).

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in first trimester.

albendazole.definition: A broad-spectrum antihelminthic agent used to treat various worm infections.

dosage.adults: 400 mg orally once or twice daily (duration depends on infection).

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

pyrantel.definition: An antihelminthic agent used to treat intestinal worm infections.
pyrantel.mechanism: Depolarizes neuromuscular junctions in helminths, causing paralysis.

dosage.adults: 11 mg/kg orally as a single dose (max 1 g).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

finasteride.definition: A 5-alpha-reductase inhibitor used to treat benign prostatic hyperplasia and male pattern baldness.
finasteride.mechanism: Inhibits conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT).

dosage.adults: BPH: 5 mg orally once daily; Alopecia: 1 mg orally once daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated (teratogenic).

ketoconazole.definition: An imidazole antifungal agent used topically and orally for fungal infections.
ketoconazole.mechanism: Inhibits ergosterol synthesis in fungal cell membranes.

dosage.adults: Topical: apply once or twice daily; Oral: 200-400 mg once daily (serious infections only).
dosage.children: Topical: same as adults; Oral: dose by weight.

contraindications: Concurrent use with certain drugs (see label)

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

epoetin alfa.definition: A recombinant erythropoietin used to treat anemia due to chronic kidney disease, chemotherapy, or HIV.
epoetin alfa.mechanism: Stimulates erythropoiesis by acting on erythroid progenitor cells.
indications: Anemia due to chemotherapy or HIV

dosage.adults: 50-100 units/kg IV or SC 3 times weekly.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

multivitamin with iron.definition: A combination supplement providing essential vitamins and iron for deficiency states.
multivitamin with iron.mechanism: Replenishes essential vitamins and iron for hematopoiesis and metabolism.

special populations.pregnancy: Indicated for supplementation.

pyridoxine.definition: Vitamin B6, used for deficiency, isoniazid-induced neuropathy, and as adjunct in some metabolic disorders.
pyridoxine.mechanism: Cofactor in amino acid, glucose, and lipid metabolism.

dosage.adults: 10-50 mg orally once daily (deficiency); 25-100 mg once daily (neuropathy).

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

oxymetholone.definition: An anabolic steroid used to treat anemia and promote weight gain.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

lenalidomide.definition: An immunomodulatory agent used to treat multiple myeloma, myelodysplastic syndromes, and lymphoma.
lenalidomide.mechanism: Inhibits angiogenesis and modulates immune response.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated (REMS program).

ferrous sulfate.definition: An oral iron supplement used to treat and prevent iron deficiency anemia.
ferrous sulfate.mechanism: Replaces iron stores needed for hemoglobin synthesis.

special populations.pregnancy: Indicated for supplementation.

ferrous fumarate.definition: An oral iron supplement used to treat and prevent iron deficiency anemia.
ferrous fumarate.mechanism: Replaces iron stores needed for hemoglobin synthesis.

special populations.pregnancy: Indicated for supplementation.

darbepoetin alfa.definition: A long-acting erythropoiesis-stimulating agent used to treat anemia due to chronic kidney disease or chemotherapy.
darbepoetin alfa.mechanism: Stimulates erythropoiesis by acting on erythroid progenitor cells.

dosage.adults: 0.45 mcg/kg IV or SC once weekly or every 2-4 weeks.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ferrous gluconate.definition: An oral iron supplement used to treat and prevent iron deficiency anemia.
ferrous gluconate.mechanism: Replaces iron stores needed for hemoglobin synthesis.

special populations.pregnancy: Indicated for supplementation.

epoetin beta-methoxy polyethylene glycol.definition: A long-acting erythropoiesis-stimulating agent used to treat anemia due to chronic kidney disease.
epoetin beta-methoxy polyethylene glycol.mechanism: Stimulates erythropoiesis by acting on erythroid progenitor cells.

dosage.adults: 0.6 mcg/kg IV or SC every 2 weeks.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

folic acid.definition: A B-vitamin used to treat and prevent folate deficiency and during pregnancy.
folic acid.mechanism: Required for DNA synthesis and red blood cell formation.

special populations.pregnancy: Indicated for supplementation.

iron polysaccharide.definition: An oral iron supplement used to treat and prevent iron deficiency anemia.
iron polysaccharide.mechanism: Replaces iron stores needed for hemoglobin synthesis.

special populations.pregnancy: Indicated for supplementation.

ferumoxytol.definition: An intravenous iron replacement product for iron deficiency anemia in adults with chronic kidney disease.
ferumoxytol.mechanism: Replaces iron stores needed for hemoglobin synthesis.
indications: Iron deficiency anemia in chronic kidney disease

dosage.adults: 510 mg IV injection, repeated in 3-8 days.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

iron sucrose.definition: An intravenous iron replacement product for iron deficiency anemia in adults with chronic kidney disease.
iron sucrose.mechanism: Replaces iron stores needed for hemoglobin synthesis.
indications: Iron deficiency anemia in chronic kidney disease

dosage.adults: 100-200 mg IV per dose, total dose varies.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

leucovorin.definition: A reduced form of folic acid used to reduce toxicity of methotrexate and enhance effects of fluorouracil.
leucovorin.mechanism: Bypasses dihydrofolate reductase blockade, replenishing folate stores.

dosage.adults: 10-25 mg IV/IM every 6 hours (methotrexate rescue); 200-500 mg/m² IV (with 5-FU).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

glutamine.definition: An amino acid supplement used for sickle cell disease and as a nutritional supplement.
glutamine.mechanism: Improves redox potential in sickle cell disease; supports protein synthesis.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

crizanlizumab.definition: A monoclonal antibody used to reduce frequency of vaso-occlusive crises in sickle cell disease.
crizanlizumab.mechanism: Binds P-selectin, blocking interactions that lead to vaso-occlusion.
indications: Sickle cell disease (to reduce vaso-occlusive crises)

dosage.adults: 5 mg/kg IV at week 0, 2, then every 4 weeks.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

propofol.definition: A short-acting intravenous anesthetic agent used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia and sedation.
propofol.mechanism: Enhances GABAergic inhibition in the CNS.

dosage.adults: Induction: 1-2.5 mg/kg IV; Maintenance: 50-200 mcg/kg/min IV infusion.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to propofol or egg/soy products

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

prilocaine.definition: An amide-type local anesthetic used for infiltration, nerve block, and topical anesthesia.
prilocaine.mechanism: Blocks sodium channels, inhibiting nerve impulse conduction.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ketamine.definition: A dissociative anesthetic used for induction and maintenance of anesthesia and procedural sedation.
ketamine.mechanism: NMDA receptor antagonist; produces dissociative anesthesia.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

contraindications: Conditions where increased BP is hazardous

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

succinylcholine.definition: A depolarizing neuromuscular blocker used for rapid sequence intubation and short procedures.
succinylcholine.mechanism: Mimics acetylcholine at neuromuscular junction, causing sustained depolarization and paralysis.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

glycopyrrolate.definition: An anticholinergic agent used to reduce secretions and as an adjunct in anesthesia.

dosage.adults: 0.1-0.2 mg IV/IM; oral: 1-2 mg 2-3 times daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

rocuronium.definition: A non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker used for muscle relaxation during surgery and intubation.
rocuronium.mechanism: Blocks acetylcholine at nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

etomidate.definition: A short-acting intravenous anesthetic used for induction of general anesthesia and procedural sedation.
etomidate.mechanism: Enhances GABAergic inhibition in the CNS.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

vecuronium.definition: A non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker used for muscle relaxation during surgery and intubation.
vecuronium.mechanism: Blocks acetylcholine at nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

hyoscyamine.definition: An anticholinergic agent used to treat GI disorders, bladder spasms, and as a pre-anesthetic.

dosage.adults: 0.125-0.25 mg orally or sublingually every 4 hours as needed.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

cisatracurium.definition: A non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker used for muscle relaxation during surgery and intubation.
cisatracurium.mechanism: Blocks acetylcholine at nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

hydromorphone.definition: A potent opioid analgesic used for moderate to severe pain.
hydromorphone.mechanism: Binds to mu-opioid receptors in the CNS, altering pain perception.

dosage.adults: Oral: 2-8 mg every 4-6 hours; IV: 0.2-1 mg every 2-3 hours.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

atracurium.definition: A non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocker used for muscle relaxation during surgery and intubation.
atracurium.mechanism: Blocks acetylcholine at nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

butorphanol.definition: A mixed agonist-antagonist opioid analgesic used for moderate to severe pain.
butorphanol.mechanism: Agonist at kappa and partial agonist/antagonist at mu opioid receptors.

dosage.adults: 1 mg IV/IM every 3-4 hours; Nasal: 1 mg (1 spray) in one nostril, may repeat in 60-90 min.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

methohexital.definition: A barbiturate anesthetic used for induction of anesthesia and procedural sedation.
methohexital.mechanism: Enhances GABAergic inhibition in the CNS.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

bisoprolol.definition: A beta-1 selective blocker used for hypertension and heart failure.
bisoprolol.mechanism: Blocks beta-1 adrenergic receptors, reducing heart rate and cardiac output.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

nifedipine.definition: A dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker used for hypertension and angina.
nifedipine.mechanism: Inhibits calcium influx into vascular smooth muscle, causing vasodilation.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

interferon alfa-2b.definition: A recombinant cytokine used to treat hepatitis B and C, certain cancers, and viral infections.
interferon alfa-2b.mechanism: Modulates immune response, inhibits viral replication and cell proliferation.

dosage.adults: 3-10 million units SC or IM 3 times weekly (varies by indication).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

iohexol.definition: A non-ionic, water-soluble radiographic contrast agent used in diagnostic imaging procedures.
iohexol.mechanism: Enhances contrast of blood vessels and tissues during imaging by increasing X-ray absorption.

dosage.adults: Dose varies by procedure and concentration.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to iohexol or iodinated contrast agents

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

danazol.definition: A synthetic androgen used to treat endometriosis, fibrocystic breast disease, and hereditary angioedema.
danazol.mechanism: Suppresses pituitary gonadotropins and increases C1 esterase inhibitor.

dosage.adults: 200-800 mg orally daily in divided doses.

contraindications: Severe hepatic, renal, or cardiac disease

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

gadobenate dimeglumine.mechanism: Shortens T1 and T2 relaxation times, enhancing MRI images.
indications: MRI of the CNS, liver, and vasculature

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

furosemide.definition: A loop diuretic used to treat edema and hypertension.
furosemide.mechanism: Inhibits Na-K-2Cl symporter in the thick ascending limb of Henle's loop.

dosage.adults: 20-80 mg orally/IV once or twice daily.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to furosemide or sulfa drugs

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

hydrochlorothiazide.definition: A thiazide diuretic used to treat hypertension and edema.
hydrochlorothiazide.mechanism: Inhibits Na-Cl symporter in the distal convoluted tubule.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

bumetanide.definition: A potent loop diuretic used to treat edema.
bumetanide.mechanism: Inhibits Na-K-2Cl symporter in the thick ascending limb of Henle's loop.

dosage.adults: 0.5-2 mg orally/IV once or twice daily.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to bumetanide or sulfa drugs

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

metolazone.definition: A thiazide-like diuretic used to treat edema and hypertension.
metolazone.mechanism: Inhibits Na-Cl symporter in the distal convoluted tubule.
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to metolazone or sulfa drugs

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

torsemide.definition: A loop diuretic used to treat edema and hypertension.
torsemide.mechanism: Inhibits Na-K-2Cl symporter in the thick ascending limb of Henle's loop.
contraindications: Hypersensitivity to torsemide or sulfa drugs

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

triamterene.definition: A potassium-sparing diuretic used to treat edema and hypertension (often in combination with thiazides).
triamterene.mechanism: Inhibits sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule, reducing potassium excretion.

dosage.adults: 100-300 mg orally daily in 1-2 divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

chlorthalidone.definition: A thiazide-like diuretic used to treat hypertension and edema.
chlorthalidone.mechanism: Inhibits Na-Cl symporter in the distal convoluted tubule.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

acetazolamide.definition: A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor diuretic used for glaucoma, altitude sickness, and edema.
acetazolamide.mechanism: Inhibits carbonic anhydrase, reducing bicarbonate reabsorption.

dosage.adults: 250-1000 mg orally daily in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

celecoxib.definition: A selective COX-2 inhibitor NSAID used for pain and inflammation.

dosage.adults: 100-200 mg orally once or twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in third trimester.

adalimumab.definition: A monoclonal antibody TNF inhibitor used to treat autoimmune diseases.
adalimumab.mechanism: Binds TNF-alpha, blocking its inflammatory effects.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

infliximab.definition: A monoclonal antibody TNF inhibitor used to treat autoimmune diseases.
infliximab.mechanism: Binds TNF-alpha, blocking its inflammatory effects.

dosage.adults: 3-10 mg/kg IV at 0, 2, 6 weeks, then every 8 weeks.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

chloramphenicol.definition: A broad-spectrum antibiotic used for serious infections when other agents are ineffective.
chloramphenicol.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit.

dosage.adults: 50-100 mg/kg/day IV or orally in divided doses.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

anthrax immune globulin intravenous.definition: A human immune globulin used as adjunctive therapy for inhalational anthrax.
anthrax immune globulin intravenous.mechanism: Provides passive immunity by supplying anti-anthrax antibodies.

dosage.adults: Dose individualized based on weight and clinical response.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

contraindications: IgA deficiency with antibodies to IgA

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

anthrax vaccine adsorbed.definition: A vaccine used to prevent anthrax infection.
anthrax vaccine adsorbed.mechanism: Induces immunity against Bacillus anthracis protective antigen.
indications: Pre-exposure and post-exposure prophylaxis of anthrax

dosage.adults: 0.5 mL IM at 0, 1, 6, 12, and 18 months, then annual boosters.

contraindications: Severe allergic reaction to previous dose

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

immune globulin intravenous.definition: A preparation of pooled human immunoglobulin G (IgG) used for immune deficiencies and autoimmune conditions.
immune globulin intravenous.mechanism: Provides passive immunity and modulates immune response.

dosage.adults: 0.4-2 g/kg IV, frequency varies by indication.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

contraindications: IgA deficiency with antibodies to IgA

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

fomepizole.definition: An antidote used to treat methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning.
fomepizole.mechanism: Inhibits alcohol dehydrogenase, preventing formation of toxic metabolites.

dosage.adults: 15 mg/kg IV loading, then 10 mg/kg every 12 hours.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

vancomycin.definition: A glycopeptide antibiotic used to treat serious Gram-positive infections.
vancomycin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding D-Ala-D-Ala terminus.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

physostigmine.definition: A reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used as an antidote for anticholinergic toxicity.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

pralidoxime.definition: An antidote for organophosphate and nerve agent poisoning.

dosage.adults: 1-2 g IV over 15-30 min, repeat as needed.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

atropine.definition: An anticholinergic agent used for bradycardia, organophosphate poisoning, and as a pre-anesthetic.

dosage.adults: 0.5-1 mg IV every 3-5 min (max 3 mg for bradycardia).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

heparin.definition: An anticoagulant used to prevent and treat thromboembolic disorders.
heparin.mechanism: Enhances antithrombin III activity, inhibiting thrombin and factor Xa.

dosage.adults: IV bolus 5,000 units, then infusion 12-18 units/kg/hr.

special populations.pregnancy: Preferred anticoagulant in pregnancy.

buspirone.definition: An anxiolytic agent used to treat generalized anxiety disorder.

dosage.adults: 10-30 mg orally daily in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

sildenafil.definition: A phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor used to treat erectile dysfunction and pulmonary arterial hypertension.
sildenafil.mechanism: Inhibits PDE-5, increasing cGMP and causing vasodilation.

dosage.adults: ED: 25-100 mg orally as needed; PAH: 20 mg orally three times daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

amantadine.mechanism: Blocks viral uncoating (influenza A); increases dopamine release (Parkinson's).
indications: Influenza A (not recommended due to resistance)

dosage.adults: 100 mg orally once or twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

warfarin.definition: An oral anticoagulant used to prevent and treat thromboembolic disorders.
warfarin.mechanism: Inhibits vitamin K-dependent clotting factor synthesis.

dosage.adults: 2-10 mg orally once daily (adjust to INR).
dosage.children: Dose by weight and INR target.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated (except in some mechanical valves).

antithrombin iii.definition: A plasma-derived anticoagulant used to treat hereditary antithrombin deficiency.

dosage.adults: Dose individualized by antithrombin activity and weight.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

antithrombin (recombinant).definition: A recombinant form of human antithrombin used to treat hereditary antithrombin deficiency.

dosage.adults: Dose individualized by antithrombin activity and weight.
dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

clonazepam.definition: A benzodiazepine used to treat seizure disorders and panic disorder.
clonazepam.mechanism: Enhances GABAergic inhibition in the CNS.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

alprazolam.definition: A benzodiazepine used to treat anxiety and panic disorders.
alprazolam.mechanism: Enhances GABAergic inhibition in the CNS.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

lorazepam.definition: A benzodiazepine used to treat anxiety, status epilepticus, and as a sedative.
lorazepam.mechanism: Enhances GABAergic inhibition in the CNS.

dosage.adults: 1-4 mg orally 2-3 times daily; IV: 4 mg for status epilepticus.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

escitalopram.definition: A selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) antidepressant.
escitalopram.mechanism: Inhibits reuptake of serotonin in the CNS.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

trazodone.definition: A serotonin antagonist and reuptake inhibitor (SARI) antidepressant, also used for insomnia.
trazodone.mechanism: Inhibits serotonin reuptake and antagonizes 5-HT2 receptors.

dosage.adults: 150-400 mg orally daily in divided doses (depression); 25-100 mg at bedtime (insomnia).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

duloxetine.mechanism: Inhibits reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine in the CNS.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

mirtazapine.definition: A tetracyclic antidepressant with noradrenergic and specific serotonergic activity.
mirtazapine.mechanism: Antagonizes central presynaptic alpha-2 adrenergic and certain serotonin receptors.

dosage.adults: 15-45 mg orally once daily at bedtime.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

quetiapine.definition: An atypical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia, bipolar disorder, and depression (adjunct).
quetiapine.mechanism: Antagonist at dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2 receptors.

dosage.adults: 150-800 mg orally daily in divided doses.
dosage.children: Dose by age and indication (age 10+ for bipolar).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.
special populations.elderly: Increased risk of mortality in dementia-related psychosis.

dipyridamole.definition: A platelet inhibitor and vasodilator used for stroke prevention and cardiac stress testing.
dipyridamole.mechanism: Inhibits platelet aggregation by increasing cAMP; vasodilates coronary arteries.

dosage.adults: 75-100 mg orally 4 times daily (stroke); IV dose for stress testing.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

iodixanol.definition: A non-ionic, iso-osmolar iodinated contrast agent for intravascular imaging.
iodixanol.mechanism: Enhances X-ray contrast by increasing absorption in blood vessels/tissues.

dosage.adults: Dose varies by procedure and concentration.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

dexmethylphenidate.definition: A CNS stimulant used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).
dexmethylphenidate.mechanism: Blocks reuptake of norepinephrine and dopamine in the brain.

dosage.adults: 10-40 mg orally daily in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

sargramostim.definition: A recombinant granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) used to stimulate white blood cell production.
sargramostim.mechanism: Stimulates production of neutrophils, monocytes, and macrophages.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by BSA.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to sargramostim or yeast-derived products

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

lymphocyte immune globulin, anti-thy (eq.definition: An immunosuppressive agent used to treat acute rejection in organ transplantation and aplastic anemia.
lymphocyte immune globulin, anti-thy (eq.mechanism: Contains antibodies that deplete T lymphocytes.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

eltrombopag.definition: A thrombopoietin receptor agonist used to treat thrombocytopenia in chronic ITP, hepatitis C, and severe aplastic anemia.
eltrombopag.mechanism: Stimulates thrombopoietin receptor, increasing platelet production.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

caffeine.definition: A CNS stimulant used to treat neonatal apnea and as a stimulant.
caffeine.mechanism: Blocks adenosine receptors, increasing neuronal activity.

dosage.adults: 100-200 mg orally every 3-4 hours as needed.
dosage.children: Neonates: 20 mg/kg IV/PO loading, then 5-10 mg/kg/day.

special populations.pregnancy: Limit intake.

carbamazepine.definition: An anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer used for epilepsy, trigeminal neuralgia, and bipolar disorder.
carbamazepine.mechanism: Blocks voltage-gated sodium channels, reducing neuronal firing.

dosage.adults: 400-1200 mg orally daily in divided doses.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

amiodarone.definition: A class III antiarrhythmic agent used to treat and prevent serious arrhythmias.
amiodarone.mechanism: Blocks potassium channels, prolonging cardiac action potential.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

verapamil.definition: A non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker used for hypertension, angina, and arrhythmias.
verapamil.mechanism: Inhibits calcium influx into cardiac and vascular smooth muscle.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

dofetilide.definition: A class III antiarrhythmic used to treat and maintain normal sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation.
dofetilide.mechanism: Blocks potassium channels, prolonging cardiac action potential.

dosage.adults: 500 mcg orally twice daily (adjust for renal function).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

mexiletine.definition: A class Ib antiarrhythmic used to treat ventricular arrhythmias.
mexiletine.mechanism: Blocks sodium channels, shortening cardiac action potential.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

disopyramide.definition: A class Ia antiarrhythmic used to treat ventricular arrhythmias and atrial fibrillation.
disopyramide.mechanism: Blocks sodium channels, prolonging cardiac action potential.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

quinidine.definition: A class Ia antiarrhythmic used to treat atrial and ventricular arrhythmias.
quinidine.mechanism: Blocks sodium channels, prolonging cardiac action potential.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

procainamide.definition: A class Ia antiarrhythmic used to treat atrial and ventricular arrhythmias.
procainamide.mechanism: Blocks sodium channels, prolonging cardiac action potential.

dosage.adults: 15-18 mg/kg IV over 30-60 min, then infusion.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

dimercaprol.definition: A chelating agent used to treat arsenic, gold, and mercury poisoning.
dimercaprol.mechanism: Binds heavy metals, forming complexes excreted in urine.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

rosuvastatin.definition: A statin used to lower cholesterol and reduce risk of cardiovascular disease.
rosuvastatin.mechanism: Inhibits HMG-CoA reductase, reducing cholesterol synthesis.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

perindopril.definition: An ACE inhibitor used to treat hypertension and heart failure.
perindopril.mechanism: Inhibits ACE, decreasing angiotensin II production and lowering blood pressure.
contraindications: History of angioedema with ACE inhibitors

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

isoxsuprine.definition: A vasodilator used to treat peripheral vascular disease and off-label for preterm labor.
isoxsuprine.mechanism: Beta-adrenergic agonist causing vasodilation of skeletal muscle.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

hydroxychloroquine.definition: An antimalarial and immunomodulatory agent used for malaria and autoimmune diseases.
hydroxychloroquine.mechanism: Inhibits heme polymerase in Plasmodium; modulates immune response.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

leflunomide.definition: A disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) used to treat rheumatoid arthritis.
leflunomide.mechanism: Inhibits pyrimidine synthesis, reducing lymphocyte proliferation.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

hydrocodone.definition: An opioid analgesic used for moderate to severe pain and as an antitussive.
hydrocodone.mechanism: Binds to mu-opioid receptors in the CNS, altering pain perception.

dosage.adults: 5-10 mg orally every 4-6 hours as needed.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

chondroitin.definition: A dietary supplement used for osteoarthritis and joint health.
chondroitin.mechanism: Component of cartilage; may reduce cartilage breakdown.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

glucosamine.definition: A dietary supplement used for osteoarthritis and joint health.
glucosamine.mechanism: Component of cartilage; may promote cartilage repair.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

etodolac.definition: A nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used for pain and inflammation.
contraindications: History of asthma, urticaria, or allergic-type reactions after NSAIDs

special populations.pregnancy: Avoid in third trimester.

mycophenolate mofetil.definition: An immunosuppressant used to prevent organ transplant rejection.
mycophenolate mofetil.mechanism: Inhibits inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase, suppressing lymphocyte proliferation.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

amiloride.definition: A potassium-sparing diuretic used to treat hypertension and heart failure.
amiloride.mechanism: Inhibits sodium reabsorption in the distal tubule, reducing potassium excretion.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ethacrynic acid.definition: A loop diuretic used to treat edema, especially in patients allergic to sulfa drugs.
ethacrynic acid.mechanism: Inhibits Na-K-2Cl symporter in the thick ascending limb of Henle's loop.

dosage.adults: 25-100 mg orally once or twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

alendronate.definition: A bisphosphonate used to treat and prevent osteoporosis and Paget's disease.

dosage.adults: 70 mg orally once weekly or 10 mg once daily.

contraindications: Inability to stand/sit upright for 30 min

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

itraconazole.definition: A triazole antifungal used to treat systemic and superficial fungal infections.
itraconazole.mechanism: Inhibits ergosterol synthesis in fungal cell membranes.
contraindications: Concurrent use with certain drugs (see label)

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated except for life-threatening infections.

amphotericin b.definition: A polyene antifungal used for serious systemic fungal infections.
amphotericin b.mechanism: Binds ergosterol, forming pores in fungal cell membranes.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

amphotericin b lipid complex.definition: A lipid formulation of amphotericin B with reduced nephrotoxicity.
amphotericin b lipid complex.mechanism: Binds ergosterol, forming pores in fungal cell membranes.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

voriconazole.definition: A triazole antifungal used to treat serious fungal infections.
voriconazole.mechanism: Inhibits ergosterol synthesis in fungal cell membranes.

dosage.adults: Loading: 6 mg/kg IV every 12h x2, then 4 mg/kg IV every 12h or 200-300 mg orally every 12h.

contraindications: Concurrent use with certain drugs (see label)

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

posaconazole.definition: A triazole antifungal used for prophylaxis and treatment of invasive fungal infections.
posaconazole.mechanism: Inhibits ergosterol synthesis in fungal cell membranes.
indications: Prophylaxis/treatment of invasive Aspergillus and Candida infections

dosage.adults: 300 mg orally/IV twice daily on day 1, then 300 mg once daily.

contraindications: Concurrent use with certain drugs (see label)

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

caspofungin.definition: An echinocandin antifungal used to treat invasive fungal infections.
caspofungin.mechanism: Inhibits synthesis of beta-(1,3)-D-glucan in fungal cell walls.

dosage.adults: Loading: 70 mg IV, then 50 mg IV daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

amphotericin b liposomal.definition: A liposomal formulation of amphotericin B with reduced nephrotoxicity.
amphotericin b liposomal.mechanism: Binds ergosterol, forming pores in fungal cell membranes.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

isavuconazonium.definition: A triazole antifungal prodrug used to treat invasive aspergillosis and mucormycosis.
isavuconazonium.mechanism: Converted to isavuconazole, which inhibits ergosterol synthesis.

dosage.adults: Loading: 372 mg IV/PO every 8h x6, then 372 mg once daily.

contraindications: Concurrent use with strong CYP3A4 inhibitors/inducers

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ipratropium.definition: An anticholinergic bronchodilator used for COPD and asthma.
ipratropium.mechanism: Blocks muscarinic receptors in bronchial smooth muscle.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

flunisolide.definition: An inhaled corticosteroid used to treat asthma.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

formoterol.definition: A long-acting beta-2 agonist bronchodilator used for asthma and COPD maintenance.
formoterol.mechanism: Stimulates beta-2 adrenergic receptors, causing bronchodilation.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

vilanterol.definition: A long-acting beta-2 agonist bronchodilator used in combination inhalers for asthma and COPD.
vilanterol.mechanism: Stimulates beta-2 adrenergic receptors, causing bronchodilation.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ciclesonide.definition: An inhaled corticosteroid used for asthma maintenance therapy.

dosage.adults: 80-320 mcg inhaled once or twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

budesonide.definition: An inhaled corticosteroid used for asthma, COPD, and inflammatory bowel disease.

dosage.adults: Inhaled: 180-720 mcg twice daily; Oral: 9 mg once daily (IBD); Rectal: 2 mg once daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

beclomethasone.definition: An inhaled corticosteroid used for asthma and allergic rhinitis.

dosage.adults: Inhaled: 40-320 mcg twice daily; Nasal: 1-2 sprays per nostril twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

calcium chloride.definition: An electrolyte supplement used to treat hypocalcemia, cardiac arrest, and hyperkalemia.
calcium chloride.mechanism: Provides calcium ions essential for muscle contraction, nerve transmission, and cardiac function.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

clotrimazole.definition: An imidazole antifungal used topically for skin and mucosal fungal infections.
clotrimazole.mechanism: Inhibits ergosterol synthesis in fungal cell membranes.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

terbinafine.definition: An allylamine antifungal used for dermatophyte and nail infections.
terbinafine.mechanism: Inhibits squalene epoxidase, blocking ergosterol synthesis.

dosage.adults: Oral: 250 mg once daily; Topical: apply once or twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

econazole.definition: An imidazole antifungal used topically for skin and mucosal fungal infections.
econazole.mechanism: Inhibits ergosterol synthesis in fungal cell membranes.

dosage.adults: Topical: apply once or twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

tolnaftate.definition: A topical antifungal agent used for dermatophyte infections.
tolnaftate.mechanism: Inhibits squalene epoxidase, blocking ergosterol synthesis.

dosage.adults: Apply to affected area twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ciclopirox.definition: A topical antifungal and anti-inflammatory agent used for skin and nail infections.

dosage.adults: Apply to affected area once or twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

miconazole.definition: An imidazole antifungal used topically for skin and mucosal fungal infections.
miconazole.mechanism: Inhibits ergosterol synthesis in fungal cell membranes.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

griseofulvin.definition: An oral antifungal used for dermatophyte infections of skin, hair, and nails.
griseofulvin.mechanism: Disrupts fungal mitosis by binding to microtubules.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

halobetasol.definition: A super-high potency topical corticosteroid for inflammatory and pruritic skin disorders.
halobetasol.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses in the skin.

dosage.adults: Apply thin layer to affected area once or twice daily for up to 2 weeks.

contraindications: Viral, fungal, or tubercular skin infections

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

pimecrolimus.definition: A topical calcineurin inhibitor used for mild to moderate atopic dermatitis.
pimecrolimus.mechanism: Inhibits T-cell activation and cytokine release.

dosage.adults: Apply thin layer to affected area twice daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

alclometasone.definition: A low- to medium-potency topical corticosteroid for mild inflammatory skin conditions.
alclometasone.mechanism: Suppresses inflammation and immune responses in the skin.

dosage.adults: Apply thin layer to affected area 2-3 times daily.
dosage.children: Safe for use in children ≥1 year.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

esmolol.definition: A short-acting beta-1 selective blocker used for rapid control of supraventricular tachycardia and hypertension.
esmolol.mechanism: Blocks beta-1 adrenergic receptors, reducing heart rate and contractility.

dosage.adults: Loading: 500 mcg/kg IV over 1 min, then 50-200 mcg/kg/min infusion.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

ibutilide.definition: A class III antiarrhythmic used for acute conversion of atrial fibrillation and flutter.
ibutilide.mechanism: Prolongs cardiac action potential by enhancing slow inward sodium current.

dosage.adults: 1 mg IV over 10 min (repeat once if needed).

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

adenosine.definition: A purine nucleoside used to treat paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).
adenosine.mechanism: Slows AV node conduction via adenosine receptors.

dosage.adults: 6 mg rapid IV push; may repeat with 12 mg if needed.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

estradiol.definition: A natural estrogen hormone used for hormone replacement therapy and contraception.
estradiol.mechanism: Binds to estrogen receptors, regulating gene expression.

dosage.adults: Oral: 0.5-2 mg daily; Transdermal: 0.025-0.1 mg patch twice weekly.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

conjugated estrogens.definition: A mixture of natural estrogens used for hormone replacement therapy.
conjugated estrogens.mechanism: Binds to estrogen receptors, regulating gene expression.

special populations.pregnancy: Contraindicated.

ziprasidone.definition: An atypical antipsychotic used for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder.
ziprasidone.mechanism: Antagonist at dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2A receptors.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

paliperidone.definition: An atypical antipsychotic used for schizophrenia and schizoaffective disorder.
paliperidone.mechanism: Antagonist at dopamine D2 and serotonin 5-HT2A receptors.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

oseltamivir.definition: A neuraminidase inhibitor antiviral used to treat and prevent influenza A and B.
oseltamivir.mechanism: Inhibits influenza virus neuraminidase, preventing viral release.
indications: Influenza A and B (treatment and prophylaxis)

dosage.adults: 75 mg orally twice daily for 5 days (treatment); once daily for prophylaxis.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

influenza virus vaccine, h5n1.definition: An inactivated vaccine for prevention of influenza A (H5N1) infection.
influenza virus vaccine, h5n1.mechanism: Induces immunity against H5N1 influenza virus.
contraindications: Severe allergic reaction to previous dose

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

tisagenlecleucel.definition: A CD19-directed CAR-T cell therapy for certain leukemias and lymphomas.
tisagenlecleucel.mechanism: Genetically modified T cells target and kill CD19+ cancer cells.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

cyanocobalamin.definition: Vitamin B12, used to treat and prevent B12 deficiency.
cyanocobalamin.mechanism: Essential cofactor for DNA synthesis and neurologic function.

dosage.adults: 100-1000 mcg IM/SC monthly or orally daily.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

dosage.children: Same as adults, dose by weight.

special populations.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks.

cefepime.definition: A fourth-generation cephalosporin antibiotic for serious bacterial infections.
cefepime.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to penicillin-binding proteins.

ceftazidime.definition: A third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic for serious Gram-negative infections, including Pseudomonas.

special populations.pregnancy: Generally considered safe.

gentamicin.definition: An aminoglycoside antibiotic for serious Gram-negative infections.
gentamicin.mechanism: Inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit.
